Federal prosecutors said Aikens was charged with one count of distributing about 31 grams of crack cocaine to an undercover Kansas City police officer. He was arrested Tuesday at his home in Kansas City, Mo., and ordered held without bond. (AP)

title: Autozone Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 12
Jets Seem Prepared To Drop Nagle
description: The Jets could be prepared to severe ties with quarterback Browning Nagle, a 25-year-old restricted free agent. Yesterday, they brought in Steve DeBerg, 40, the oldest player in the National Football League and expected a visit tomorrow from Dave Krieg, 35, the Kansas City Chiefs backup.

title: Doskocil Cos.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included a $ 500,000 provision for plant closings for the quarter and year. The year also included $ 1.5 million in charges under two employment agreements, and after an accounting charge of $ 34,426,000, or $ 4.64 a share, on the adoption of SFAS 106.c-Net lossd-Included a $ 32 million provision for plant closings for the quarter and year.Year-ago periods' sales included $ 38.5 million in sales for the quarter and $ 133.8 million for the year from the discontinued pork slaughter business as well as from other unprofitable product lines that were eliminated during fiscal 1992.Doskocil said that its latest quarter was ''favorably impacted by cost reduction programs and by the elimination of losses from the discontinued fresh pork business that amounted to'' $ 900,000. These were partially offset by an ongoing noncash charge of $ 200,000 resulting from the adoption of SFAS 106 and higher interest charges.(Loss)

title: Staples Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Staples said that fiscal 1994 included a pretax charge of $ 7.6 million for revised computer strategy.

title: Democrats and Republicans Vying for High Ground on Crime
description: The tide of anti-crime proposals floating around Albany rose yet higher today as Democrats and Republicans unveiled separate measures they hope will keep them at the forefront of this year's get-tough politics.

title: Harvey Leibenstein, Harvard Professor, 71
description: Harvey Leibenstein, an author and professor of economics at Harvard University for 20 years, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 71.

title: Annual Ritual Begins as Cuomo and Legislators Argue Over Forecasts of Tax Revenue
description: The backroom sparring over the state budget began in earnest this week as Democratic and Republican legislative leaders said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has underestimated tax revenues for the coming fiscal year, and they called on him to make deeper tax cuts and increase spending on schools, parks and social programs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Whither Wuthering Heights? Some celebrities are enraged by proposals to build wind farms in and around the English village of Haworth, where the Bronte sisters lived, and on the surrounding moors that inspired Emily Bronte when she wrote her romantic novel.

title: Apply What U.S. Learned in Bosnia to Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes Cast From Sickbed
description: Propped up on a hospital bed and surrounded by aides, a frail Representative William H. Natcher was wheeled onto the floor of the House of Representatives today so he could maintain his perfect voting record.

title: Punter Gets $2 Million
description: CHRIS MOHR is staying with the Buffalo Bills under a $2 million, three-year deal that will make him the highest-paid punter in the National Football League. The contract, agreed to Wednesday, will pay the kicker about $670,000 a year, including a $700,000 signing bonus. Mohr earned $350,000 last season.

title: Indistinct Picture of Shooting Suspect
description: An emerging portrait of Rashid Baz, incomplete and often contradictory, seems notable mostly for its lack of distinction.

title: Surprising Thorpe Rides the Breeze
description: As he looked over his final shot of the day in the first round of the Doral-Ryder Open, Jim Thorpe pulled some grass from the ground and tossed it into the air. He watched as the howling west wind whisked it away, blowing it some 15 yards in a split second, and he smiled.

title: Notice the Steel Strike? 48 Hours Sum Up a Slide
description: A steelworkers' strike used to be feared as a catastrophic event, with the President sometimes preparing the nation for an economic jolt. But on Tuesday, steelworkers staged a strike against a major manufacturer here in the Rust Belt, and hardly anyone outside this region noticed. By this morning, the strike was over and workers were returning to the mills.

title: United Nations Journal; The Peacekeeper in Chief Needs More Soldiers
description: "Frankly, if the response of governments remains the way it is today, we couldn't get another operation off the ground," said Kofi Annan, the soft-spoken Ghanian who heads the United Nations peacekeeping department, as he surveyed his empire from his 37th-floor office, stuffed with African carvings, medals and plaques.

title: Art in Review
description: Alice Neel Robert Miller Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through March 19

title: Russia Shows Life Signs Beyond Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Finally Put a Stop to Nets' Winning Ways
description: It was important that the Knicks finally beat the Nets. It was more significant that the Knicks played as if their self-confidence had returned.

title: Clinton Defends Idea of Regional Insurance Pool, but Offers to Bend
description: Moving to address growing concerns about how his health care plan would work, President Clinton said today that one of its central provisions -- the creation of regional insurance pools known as health alliances -- is neither bureaucratic nor unworkable.

title: JUDGE ACCUSES G.M. OVER PICKUP DATA
description: A Federal judge in South Carolina says he believes that lawyers for the General Motors Corporation may have destroyed, or been aware of the destruction of, documents related to a fire-prone G.M. pickup truck that has been the subject of lawsuits.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. on Health Care: Seeking a Second Opinion
description: The health care issue should be rich with opportunity for the Republicans these days, with President Clinton's plan sagging in the polls and the Democrats still struggling for consensus in the relevant committees on Capitol Hill.

title: Aides Disavowed
description: President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen both moved abruptly to disassociate themselves from the conduct of aides who met privately three times in recent months to review the status of a confidential investigation into an Arkansas savings and loan. Article, page A22.

title: A Long Struggle for a Longer Runway
description: For nearly six years La Guardia Airport has been seeking permission to add a safety area beyond a notoriously short runway where an accident occurred on Wednesday evening, but the effort has been slowed by bureaucratic reviews and local opposition, officials said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Sometimes Assists Go Beyond Court
description: IN a world that features warning sirens after turnovers on consecutive possessions, it somehow makes sense that the recent four-game Knick losing streak would be considered the beginning of the end of civilization as we know it. At the very least, the struggle has forced a group of players operating under championship demands to rearrange the Steinberg maps in their heads. Somewhere to the west, those imposing obstacles in Chicago, Houston, Phoenix and Seattle have recently been replaced, at least temporarily, by the threat of a duplex in Sacramento and a rapidly growing skyscraper across the Hudson. Sacramento? East Rutherford? They don't make vistas like they used to.

title: PRESIDENT REVIVES TOUGH TRADE STEP TO PRESSURE JAPAN
description: President Clinton signed an executive order today that gives him authority to impose strong trade sanctions quickly against Japan if it fails to open its markets.

title: Art in Review
description: James Turrell Barbara Gladstone Gallery 99 Greene Street SoHo Through March 12

title: INSIDE
description: Giuliani Severance Proposal Accepted by Union Leaders

title: Esiason Doesn't Shy From Business
description: Jets quarterback Boomer Esiason looks around the National Football League and cannot understand why the players voted in favor of a collective-bargaining agreement that stands to divide them into two categories: the haves and the have-nots.

title: Review/Art; Miniature World of Humans and Gods A
description: Sex? Violence? Exotic scenery? Current events? Domestic drama? Forget television; take a look at Indian painting. It's all there in "The Greatest Delight: Painting of India From the Williams College Museum of Art" at the Equitable Gallery, an exhibition short on top-of-the-line work but historically wide-ranging and full of individual pleasures. Most of the paintings are small, meant to be held in the hand and viewed close-up, but each encompasses a whole world of ideas and sensations.

title: Kudlow Out at Bear, Stearns; Outspoken Chief Economist
description: Lawrence A. Kudlow, the outspoken chief economist of Bear, Stearns & Company, abruptly resigned yesterday.

title: TV Weekend; That's Entertainment, by Way of Jerry Herman
description: Public television is starting another pledge period and that means at least one glitzy tribute to the Broadway musical. Carrying the big banner this time is tonight's "Jerry Herman's Broadway at the Bowl," taped last summer at the Hollywood Bowl.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Women Create a Melting Pot
description: There is a mythical male fashion designer who appears in the mind of outraged women shoppers, taking the blame for all of fashion's foibles: a Machiavellian figure sticking pins into a squealing fitting model, a helium giggle escaping from him as he imagines a woman in Oklahoma arriving at her neighbor's barbecue in a negligee. Or a baby-doll dress.

title: President Criticizes Briefings on Inquiry
description: President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen moved today to disassociate themselves from the conduct of aides who met privately three times in recent months to review the status of a confidential investigation into an Arkansas savings and loan association.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Guide column of the Long Island Weekly on Sunday gave an incorrect date for an appearance by Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker, makers of the film "The War Room." They will speak at the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington at 7 o'clock tonight, not tomorrow night.

title: Laurence Hugo, 76, Stage and TV Actor
description: Laurence Hugo, an actor who appeared in the original production of "Stalag 17" and starred in the television daytime drama "The Edge of Night" for 11 years, died on Wednesday at Cedars Nursing Home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 76 and lived in Rockfish, Va.

title: Apple's Newton Reborn: Will It Still the Critics?
description: As consumer products go, it may be comparable to Ford's seeking a second chance for the Edsel. On Friday, Apple Computer will bring out an improved Newton.

title: It's Not Exactly Moscow on the Hudson, but It Will Do
description: After less than two seasons in New York, Aleksei Kovalev of the Rangers and Darius Kasparaitis of the Islanders have caught on quickly to the intensity of the local rivalry.

title: Review/Film; Naughtiness in Pooh Land
description: In a bosky Australian hideaway, the artist Norman Lindsay (Sam Neill) follows his muse. Actually there are quite a few muses, scampering through the gardens in various states of undress and posing thoughtfully for what look like Playboy pictorials on "The Girls of Pre-Raphaelite Kitsch." The painter, whose wife and sweet little daughters are also on the premises, makes a point of never being distracted by such goings-on. After all, he is an artist with a serious mission. He lives to glorify the human body and appall the bourgeoisie.

title: Three Brothers Are Convicted In Art Thefts
description: Three brothers accused of spending more than a decade as members of a brazen group that crashed vehicles into fur salons, jewelry stores and art galleries in New York City and then stole millions of dollars in luxury items were convicted yesterday on racketeering and related charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Mexico's Fine Line
description: As peasant rebels roamed the highlands outside this city in early January, bombs exploded in the capital and investors began to sell off their Mexican stocks, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari shelved plans for a crackdown on rebel supporters, dismissed his hard-line Interior Minister and declared a unilateral cease-fire.

title: Morris Goes Deep, But Nets Fall Flat
description: Unlike Tuesday night, when he set a club record by making six 3-point shots, Chris Morris didn't find his long-range shot until the buzzer at the end of the third quarter last night.

title: Art in Review
description: Morris Hirshfield Sidney Janis Gallery 110 West 57th Street Manhattan Through March 19

title: Proffitt's Department Stores To Buy McRae's Retail Chain
description: Proffitt's Inc., a regional department store chain based in Knoxville, Tenn., announced yesterday that it was purchasing privately held McRae's Inc. with a combination of $337 million in cash, debt and equity.

title: In Trash Crunch, Giuliani Looks Out of State
description: With New York City's only remaining landfill filling up, the Giuliani administration has decided to search for out-of-state landfills willing to take about a third of the garbage the city produces each year, city officials said yesterday.

title: Nosair Asks for a Halt to Bloodshed
description: Saying he mourned for Jewish as well as Arab victims of violence, the man acquitted once and accused again in the 1990 murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane has called on both sides to build "the bridge for peace" in the Middle East.

title: Mickelson Breaks Leg Skiing
description: Phil Mickelson, the brightest young star on the PGA Tour, suffered a broken leg in a skiing accident in Flagstaff, Ariz., today. Mickelson, 23 years old, fell while skiing at the Arizona Snowball ski area and broke his upper leg.

title: On My Mind; The Mideast Fantasy
description: Five years ago this month about 50 Arab and Israeli intellectuals and diplomats met near a lake in Switzerland to pretend that their nations and peoples were at peace.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Defending Henry Higgins

title: Cortines Orders Bronx Board to Renew a Contract
description: Toughening his posture after repeated attempts at conciliation, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines ordered a Bronx community school board yesterday to renew the contract of a superintendent who Mr. Cortines said has enacted reforms and cleaned up corruption.

title: Healthy Gains in Retail Sales Despite February's Big Chill
description: Neither rain, sleet, snow nor credit cards charged to the limit thwarted shoppers, who turned out in force to make February the best retail sales month since the robust Christmas spending spree in 1992.

title: Hayes Wheels Int'l reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included net gain of $ 1.6 million, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in a Brazilian affiliate.c-After an accounting charge of $ 24.6 million, or $ 1.40 a share, from the adoption of FASB 106, 109, and 112.Share earnings are pro forma figures which were restated for the restructuring from the December 1992 initial public offering. Actual net earnings for the year-ago quarter were 8 cents a share on 9,100,667 average shares outstanding, and actual net earnings for the prior year were 40 cents a share.Fiscal 1993 results included ongoing costs for FASB 106 of $ 3.4 million, or 19 cents a share, compared to $ 700,000, or 4 cents a share, in fiscal 1992.Latest year's results were break-even.

title: Review/Film; A Land Grab, This Time In Vermont
description: The real-life story behind "Where the Rivers Flow North" is the stuff of independent film makers' fantasies. A Vermonter named Jay Craven put together the money for his film from a variety of sources, ranging from foreign sales rights to local small investors, and made the kind of period piece that would be produced in Hollywood only as a fluke.

title: Jordan: Two Strikeouts and One Error
description: If Michael Jordan was His Airness in the National Basketball Association, he proved to be His Errorness in the first game of his baseball career.

title: Dorette Kruse Fleischmann; Civic Leader, 88
description: Dorette Kruse Fleischmann, a civic leader and socialite in New York and Cincinnati, died yesterday at the Racquet Club in Chicago. She was 88.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with an article about European stock markets in Business Day yesterday transposed the closing figures for two indexes in some copies. The FTSE-100 index of British stocks closed Wednesday at 3,248.1; the DAX-30 index of German stocks closed at 2,020.33.

title: Review/Theater: Damn Yankees; A Faustian Fable From the Era Of Eisenhower
description: LATE in the second act of "Damn Yankees," the Devil, otherwise known as Applegate, and Lola, his chief henchwoman in damnation, are picking their way across the stage, blanketed in fog. Where are we? she asks. Pointing a flashlight at the audience and peering out into the darkness, he says, "Look, this is limbo."

title: Big Investors Suffer as Foreign Markets Sour
description: Investment firms and banks that like to make big bets in the world's financial markets routinely lose millions of dollars here and millions of dollars there on the expectation that taking risks with investments can reap handsome rewards.

title: 6% of Women Report Beatings While Pregnant
description: At least 6 percent of pregnant women are battered by their spouses or partners, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a study released today.

title: Blackmun Tackles Question of Who Shall Die; Legislating From Bench
description: To the Editor:

title: Blackmun Tackles Question of Who Shall Die; 'Cruel and Unusual'
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Chiefs Accept Plan On Severance
description: The leaders of New York City's municipal labor unions said yesterday that they would accept one of the essential components of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's preliminary budget plan: severance payments to cut at least 7,600 jobs from the government payroll.

title: Bon-Ton Stores Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After a benefit of $ 1.5 million, or 14 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Chevrolet to Replace 'Heartbeat' Theme
description: Chevrolet will soon introduce a replacement campaign for "The Heartbeat of America," a theme that has become one of the most familiar in advertising since it began appearing in the fall of 1986. The new campaign, by Lintas Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., will carry the theme "Genuine Chevrolet."

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Tuesday about the sale of The Chicago Sun-Times misstated the timing of The Chicago Tribune's price increase to 50 cents a copy. The price went up in September 1992, not last spring.

title: Private Guards Urged for U.S. Aides in Somalia
description: The commander of United States forces in Somalia said today that he had recommended that the State Department hire private security to guard American diplomats after American troops leave Somalia this month.

title: Nassau Legislature Plan Seeks 2 Minority Districts
description: Nassau County's new legislature would be drawn from 19 legislative districts, two dominated by minority voters, under a plan devised by demographic consultants for the county's charter revision commission.

title: ARCO RAISES CLEANUP ESTIMATES BY $1 BILLION
description: In a disclosure made to satisfy new securities regulations, ARCO estimated that environmental cleanups could cost $1 billion more than it had set aside for the purpose. Many analysts said they expected that other industrial giants would be forced to follow ARCO's lead.

title: Gold Is Ignoring Wall St.'s Inflation Fears
description: Why, if gold is such a good indicator of inflation, as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, recently told Congress, have traders around the world shunned gold?

title: United Airlines Starts A Two-Tier Pay Scale
description: Two-tier wages, an idea that many airlines and their unions embraced in the early 1980's to cut costs but later abandoned because it hurt morale, have made a comeback at United Airlines.

title: Corrections
description: An article and headline on Feb. 23 about allegations of a kickback scheme in the space program referred imprecisely in some copies to the criminal charges filed. Charges were filed against only one NASA contractor; the Martin Marietta and General Electric corporations were not charged.

title: T. L. Blakemore, 78, Expert on Japan's Law
description: Thomas L. Blakemore, an American lawyer who was an expert on Japanese law and whose Tokyo law firm represented many United States companies in Asia, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Seattle. He was 78.

title: Kenyan Breaking Marks at a Record Age
description: On Saturday, when the USA/Mobil indoor track and field championships are held for the first time in the Georgia Dome, Moses Kiptanui will try to break his world indoor record for 3,000 meters. Today, in an interview that told much about the race and the man, the gifted 23-year-old Kenyan talked of how and why he hoped to lower his record.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-15 CLINTON REVIVES TRADE LAW President Clinton signed an executive order that would allow him to impose trade sanctions against Japan if it did not open its markets. The move angered the Tokyo Government and GATT officials. A1 LITTLE ACTION ON ISRAELI SETTLERS Five days after Israel approved tough measures against militant settlers, no one in Kfar Tapuah has seen an official piece of paper ordering the return of a gun. A1

title: 3 Are Awarded $27.9 Million In Implant Trial
description: A Houston jury has awarded three women a total of $27.9 million in damages in a lawsuit charging the 3M Corporation and two smaller companies with making silicone breast implants that leaked, causing severe illnesses.

title: Exploration Co.
description: Shares of the Exploration Company of Louisiana, whose 52-week low was 37.5 cents a share in December, closed yesterday at $1.125 a share, down 6.25 cents. The company got a boost on Wednesday when an analyst on Dan Dorfman's program on CNBC said that Exploration's shares could rise to as high as $10 if an offshore oil well in China is successful.

title: The Good Side of Sharks on Display
description: Like tigers and tyrannosaurs, sharks are scary predators, but although their monstrous triangular teeth are the stuff of horror movies, real-life sharks rarely devour hapless swimmers. Still, sharks are interesting creatures even after their evil reputation is reduced to a realistic size, and a traveling exhibition that is now at the American Museum of Natural History is worth a visit.

title: Moe Climbs Another Mountain and Finds a Shoebox Filled With Cookies
description: For Tommy Moe, being here for a World Cup ski race means being back home in America among adoring fans and a shoebox filled with the freshly baked cookies that his grandmother sent from Whitefish, Mont.

title: In Proposal, Vincent Memoir Airs Criticisms
description: In a proposal for a memoir about his three years as baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent snipes at high-profile owners such as George M. Steinbrenner 3d, Peter O'Malley, Jerry Reinsdorf and Bud Selig, describes Bart Giamatti's unhappiness as National League president before becoming commissioner and says unequivocally that Pete Rose gambled on baseball.

title: Art in Review
description: Richmond Burton Matthew Marks Gallery 1018 Madison Avenue (near 78th Street) Through March 19

title: Review/Dance; Cinematic Impressions Of Desire's Intensity
description: There was a time when nothing seemed more French than a movie in which Jean Gabin, with jaded eye, watched Brigitte Bardot raise her dress above her thighs. L'Esquisse, an admirable French experimental dance troupe directed by Regis Obadia and Joelle Bouvier, has infused the same 1950's film noir atmosphere into "Welcome to Paradise."

title: CHRONICLE
description: VERNON A. WALTERS, the United States Ambassador to Bonn from 1989 to 1991, made himself controversial at home but beloved by many German officials for announcing as soon as he assumed the post that the handwriting was on the wall -- the Berlin wall.

title: P.L.O. Envoy Pushes to Restart Peace Talks
description: A senior Palestinian official sent here to discuss conditions for resuming peace talks had encouraging words today, saying an agreement with Israel was the best way to ensure security for Palestinians.

title: Abroad at Home; A Lesson Too Late
description: Opponents of firm Western action to stop Serbian aggression and genocide have argued that we would only make things worse by intervening. And besides, they said, we have no security interest in a far-off conflict in the Balkans.

title: CML Group reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Per-share figures reflected a 3-for-2 stock split last August.Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Restaurants
description: Forget about the discreet setting. Forget the fact that every woman in the room seems to have come straight from her hairdresser and most of the men are manicured. Forget the soft golden light, the quiet hush that fills the air, the waiters standing smartly at attention. When the piadina arrives at your table, roll up your sleeves, daub the round flat bread with tangy squaquerone cheese, pick it up in your fingers, close your eyes and imagine that you are in the Romagna area of northeast Italy eating this rustic dish at some country counter.

title: MOTOROLA REDUCES PRICES ON NEWEST COMPUTER CHIP
description: Motorola Inc. yesterday cut prices on its latest computer chip by 15 percent, less than a month after I.B.M. trimmed its price for the microprocessor. The move keeps prices roughly comparable for both sellers of the PowerPC 601 chip and increases the pressure on the Intel Corporation, the dominant maker of chips for personal computers. The PowerPC 601 is the first in the family of processors based on RISC, or reduced instruction set computing, jointly developed by the International Business Machines Corporation, Motorola and Apple Computer Inc. It is promoted as an alternative to Intel's Pentium chip.

title: Anti-Gay Rights Move Blocked
description: The state Supreme Court today unanimously struck from November's ballot a proposal to amend the Florida Constitution in order to ban local laws that protect homosexuals from discrimination. The court said the proposal violated state law by dealing with more than one subject. It also ruled that the ballot language was misleading. The decision dealt only with the wording of the proposal, not its intent. The amendment was sponsored by the American Family Association of Florida, a conservative religious group.

title: Giants' Collins A Coveted Cover Man
description: A good cover man is hard to find, and that is why Giants cornerback Mark Collins is one of the hottest free agents in the market.

title: Home Video
description: Two new releases from Home Vision of Chicago amply demonstrate how much videos of the fine arts benefit from inventive approaches.

title: Reviews/Film; The Detective as Accessory
description: "China Moon" is such a shameless rip-off it should have been called something more honest, like "Body Heat: The Return," or "The New Adventures of Body Heat," or "Body Heat With a Couple of Different People." This film is a lot less effective than the genuine "Body Heat," the steamy 1981 thriller in which Kathleen Turner found in William Hurt just what she was looking for: a guy dumb enough to help her kill her rich husband. But even second-generation copies have their modest charms, and "China Moon" is absorbing and twisty enough to keep an audience watching.

title: Reviews/Film; Emotional Adventures Of a Spunky Heroine
description: The title character in "Angie" is supposed to be a tough, wisecracking, not-too-worldly office worker from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. She may be spirited and feisty, but her basic attributes hardly bring Geena Davis to mind. In light of that, Ms. Davis's presence doesn't guarantee "Angie" much verisimilitude, but rarely has authenticity counted for less. Ms. Davis, whose performance is exhilaratingly funny and touching, compensates for her lack of grit by sending this film's goddess quotient over the moon.

title: Conservative U.S. Judge Offers A Word on Drugs: Decriminalize
description: A conservative Federal judge whose confirmation to the bench was delayed two years by the opposition of liberals says that after hearing cases in the District Court here since 1990, he is convinced that drugs should be decriminalized and that the nation's antidrug policy is as misguided as Prohibition was.

title: Critic's Choice/Dance; Freshness and Energy Of Well-Trained Youth
description: Spring arrives a little early this year: tomorrow afternoon at the Joyce Theater, to be exact. The occasion is a heartwarming, spirited program put together by Feld Ballets/NY starring the children of the company-associated New Ballet School, in new and recent works choreographed for them by Eliot Feld and others.

title: Rutgers Honors Jordan
description: EDDIE JORDAN, the point guard who led Rutgers to the Final Four in 1976 and set career marks for assists and steals, was among four people selected for induction into the school's basketball hall of fame. Former coach BILL FOSTER (1963-71) and two other players, LARRY GORDON ('54) and BUCKY HATCHETT ('50), will also be inducted. At Rutgers, Jordan had 585 assists and 220 steals, and his 1,632 points are the sixth-best in school history. He is currently an assistant coach with the Sacramento Kings. (AP)

title: Britain Accused of Tinkering on Malaysian Dam
description: A huge aid project to construct a hydroelectric dam in Malaysia has turned into a source of grief for the British Government, leading to a trade boycott from Kuala Lumpur and a costly political fight over using foreign aid to obtain defense contracts.

title: Complex Picture Is Emerging Of Gunman in Van Shootings
description: The man accused in the Brooklyn Bridge shooting was arraigned under heavy security early yesterday with the prosecution emphasizing that he was alone in attacking a van of rabbinical students and with no official evidence yet emerging that he might have been part of a larger conspiracy.

title: Ralph Bennett, 93, Physicist and Head Of 2 Research Labs
description: Dr. Ralph Decker Bennett, a physicist who retired as research director of the Martin Marietta Corporation in 1966, died in Concord Hospital on Feb. 15 while visiting friends in Concord, N.H. He was 93 and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Treasury Prices Drop On More Inflation Fears
description: Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday, despite a return to relative stability in world bond markets. On Wednesday, a plunge in world bond markets set off selling of American Treasury securities.

title: Berkley (W.R.) Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $ 2,044,000, or 11 cents a share, from job separation arrangements, including those incurred for restructuring of Signet Star Holdings Inc.b-After an accounting benefit of $ 5,902,000, or 33 cents a share, from the adoption of FASB 109.The latest periods included investment gains of $ 5,624,000 for the quarter and $ 21,731,000 for the year, compared with $ 959,000 and $ 3,356,000 for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Indian Chief and Waterbury's Mayor Announce Plan for a Casino
description: The leaders of an embattled Indian tribe and a financially struggling Connecticut city joined today in an imaginative economic development project intended to solve all their problems and realize all their dreams: a gigantic casino that would generate more than a billion dollars a year.

title: Review/Fashion; Armani Adds Tunics to His Galaxy
description: What makes Giorgio Armani so special? Every designer here has access to fine materials and great workmanship. But for 20 years, Armani has been a star, attracting women who care about clothes and want to be comfortable in them. He changes his styles modestly, not making a point of obsolescence.

title: Review/Music; The Vienna Philharmonic Holds True to Its Traditions
description: Some of the most remarkable musical experiences of recent seasons have been associated with visits of the Vienna Philharmonic to New York City. In 1989, there was a gripping, transcendent interpretation of Bruckner's Eighth Symphony led by Herbert von Karajan in his last appearance here. Two years ago, an architectural map of Mahler's consciousness seemed to be displayed in Loren Maazel's reading of the Fifth Symphony.

title: It's All Up to Rangers; That About Covers It
description: What a pleasure watching the professional professionals back on center ice, whacking each other's knees with a glad, uncomplicated malice, rarely complaining or explaining, never crying over a split lace, never taking a victory lap with a babe in arms. And when the pro pros go to Disney World, it is because one of their teams is a sideshow there.

title: Dress Barn Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Paul Harris Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: The previous year's net income/loss, share earnings and shares outstanding were not available because the company adopted fresh start accounting in mid-year 1992.

title: U.S. Ready to Help Ukraine and Georgia, if They Help Themselves
description: With Ukraine having tentatively agreed to destroy its nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today that President Clinton would double aid to Ukraine, to about $700 million a year.

title: The Way Back to the Mideast Table
description: Yasir Arafat is undoubtedly sincere in telling Washington he wants to get back to the bargaining table with Israel as soon as Palestinian anger over the Hebron massacre subsides. He wants to complete arrangements for the beginning of Palestinian self-rule in the occupied territories. But he insists that Israel first take steps that go well beyond the framework for self-rule that both sides agreed to last summer. That reaches too far.

title: At the Bar; A California appeals court comes to grips with a question: Just how stupid can some judges be?
description: Can a judicial edict be so outrageous, so irrational, so megalomaniacal that it simply cannot be real? Or, given the errant behavior of some judges, can even the most bizarre mandate appear genuine? That question was recently before an appellate court in California.

title:
About Real Estate;
New Housing on S.I. for Low-Income Elderly
description: A rental enclave for the low-income elderly has replaced a vacant litter-strewn lot amid the modest rows of one- and two-family homes in the Port Richmond section of Staten Island.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Robinson Keeps Purdue in Big Ten Race Glenn Robinson, Division I's leading scorer, had 31 points last night night and No. 9 Purdue defeated No. 18 Minnesota, 86-70, in West Lafayette, Ind., keeping alive its chances of winning the Big Ten championship. Purdue (24-4 over all, 12-4 Big Ten) moved within one-half game of first-place Michigan (12-3) by beating Minnesota (19-10, 9-7) for the 12th consecutive time in Mackey Arena. (AP) Kansas 97, Iowa St. 79: Richard Scott had a career-high 24 points in his final home game as No. 12 Kansas routed Iowa State in Lawrence, Kan. (AP)

title: U.S.-Japan Cellular Pact Held Near
description: The United States and Japan are moving closer to an agreement that would avert pending sanctions against Japan by vastly accelerating access to Japan's cellular telephone market for American equipment.

title: Gary Wood, 52, Giants Quarterback And Cornell Star
description: Gary Wood, the stocky, scrappy quarterback who set Cornell and Ivy League records before joining the Giants in 1964, died Tuesday night at his home in Dix Hills, L.I. He was 52.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: BROOKLYN BRIDGE SHOOTING: COMPLEX PICTURE OF SUSPECT EMERGES

title: Inside Art
description: "The Art Show" wasn't a showcase just for dealers. Sotheby's also participated in the five-day event, which closed on Monday at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan. But the auction house's presence was obvious only to the handful of experts who knew the history of the 20 Miro sculptures on view at the Acquavella Galleries booth.

title: Art in Review
description: Sherrie Levine Marian Goodman Gallery 24 West 57th Street Manhattan Through April 2

title: ACTAVA REPORTS QUARTERLY LOSS AND SUSPENDS DIVIDEND
description: Actava Group, the struggling maker of recreational products formerly called Fuqua Industries, yesterday announced a steep loss, suspended its dividend indefinitely and said it was searching for a new president. The company, based in Atlanta, blamed persistent troubles at Snapper, its lawn and garden equipment business, for its fourth-quarter loss. Actava said it had taken Snapper off the auction block, having failed to attract buyers. Actava has set up a committee of independent directors to seek a successor for Charles R. Scott, Actava's president and chief executive. Shares of Actava fell $1.375, to $7, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Art in Review
description: Chuck Hoberman Museum of Modern Art 11 West 53d Street Manhattan Through April 12

title: Northwestern Steel & Wire (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss; the year was after a charge of $ 39,778,000, or $ 2.19 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Bitter Goodbye: Russians Leave Germany
description: As several companies of Russian soldiers bid their farewells to Germany one recent evening, their mood was as cold and bitter as the night air outside the shabby train station here.

title: Violence Against Hasidim Shatters Barriers Among Jews
description: When racial violence engulfed the Lubavitch Hasidic community of Crown Heights in 1991, it was more than a week before New York City's mainstream Jewish establishment rallied to the side of the Lubavitchers with expressions of support. But on Tuesday, when a group of Lubavitch students were shot by a gunman, there was no such delay.

title: Kenetech Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago periods' results were unavailable. Kenetech went public in September.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.(Loss)

title: Following the Scent: On the Trail Of the Best Burgers in Town
description: WITH all the talk about the return of the steakhouse to New York, you would think nobody had eaten beef in recent years. So what's a hamburger, chopped liver?

title: White House Ethics Meltdown
description: From now on, President Clinton says, "everyone will be much more sensitive" about attending the improper meetings between White House and Treasury officials concerning the Resolution Trust Corporation's inquiry into a savings and loan association with close ties to him and Mrs. Clinton.

title: Prudential Accord Appealed
description: Three investors in Prudential Securities Inc.'s energy partnerships filed an appeal today of the $90 million settlement between the securities firm and 116,000 investors.

title: Canadian TV Gets Olympics Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Test for Data Base Services
description: The Prodigy Services Company and America Online Inc., two large computer data base services, will compete for the endorsement of the American Federation of Teachers, a labor union with 835,000 members.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Private Fun

title: Confessions of a Video Glutton
description: STOP me before I rent again.

title: Bullish Chrysler Moves To Beef Up Auto Plants
description: The Chrysler Corporation, bullish about its long-term prospects after introducing several highly acclaimed new car and truck models, said today that it would spend $1.8 billion over three years to increase its manufacturing capacity by 17 percent.

title: Whitman's Plan For 5% Tax Cut Passes in Senate
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman made good on the first installment of her principal campaign promise today as the New Jersey Senate, following the Assembly's lead, readily approved her plan to cut the state income tax by 5 percent retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: Ailing Van Basten Out of World Cup
description: The Dutch soccer star MARCO VAN BASTEN will miss the World Cup because his ankle injury is healing too slowly, Dr. MARC MARTENS said yesterday from Brussels after examining the forward. Van Basten did not want to put his career at risk for a shot at this summer's tournament in the United States, Martens said. Van Basten, 29, a three-time European player of the year, plays for A.C. Milan. Martens operated on Van Basten's right ankle in June. (AP)

title: Review/Film; Antihero and Rich Girl Amok on a Freeway
description: Adam Rifkin's satirical comedy, "The Chase," takes one of Hollywood's most sure-fire adrenaline-pumping devices, a high-speed car chase, and turns it on its ear with a malicious, flailing glee. Virtually the entire movie takes place on the freeway between the outskirts of Los Angeles and the Mexican border as a routine police action rapidly escalates into a grotesque media circus. Anyone who has ever loathed the way television news anchors camouflage the medium's insatiable appetite for live-action excitement under a guise of pious concern will get some nasty chuckles out of the film.

title: Man Held In Slaying In Subway
description: A purse-snatching suspect was arrested Wednesday and charged with pushing a subway rider into a moving train 11 days ago, the transit police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that close soon: Closing This Weekend "THE AU PAIR MAN," Irish Repertory Theater Company, 28th Street Theater, 120 West 28th Street, Chelsea. Hugh Leonard's comedy about an Irish debt collector who becomes the companion of an Englishwoman, with Charlotte Moore and Ciaran O'Reilly; directed by Brian Murray. Through Sunday. Performances: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $20 for matinees; $25 for Friday and Saturday evenings. Information: (212) 279-4200.

title: Olympians on the Farm
description: The Olympic hockey players BRIAN SAVAGE and JIM CAMPBELL,both centers, were assigned to Fredericton of the American Hockey League by the Montreal Canadiens yesterday.

title: A Shift in Soloists
description: Because of scheduling conflicts, the violinist Kyung-Wha Chung will not appear with the New York Chamber Symphony this weekend at the 92d Street Y. In her place, the Czech pianist Ivan Moravec will be the soloist in Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto. The remainder of the all-Beethoven program is unchanged, with Gerard Schwarz conducting the Fourth and Sixth Symphonies. The concerts are to be tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 at the Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: GAP INC. (N)
description: Gap Inc., the T-shirt and jeans merchant that has added fashion merchandise to its racks, said yesterday that net income rose an unexpected 66 percent in the fourth quarter. The company's shares surged $1.125 yesterday, to $46.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Islamic Figure's Speech Plunges Howard University Into Debate on Racism
description: A week after a series of speakers railed against Jews at a rally at Howard University, the prestigious black institution has been plunged into the debate over black anti-Semitism.

title: Ex-N.H.L. Union Leader Is Facing Federal Charges
description: Alan Eagleson, whose overlapping roles as an agent, union leader and tournament organizer made him one of hockey's most powerful individuals for more than two decades, has been charged with 32 counts of racketeering, fraud and embezzlement, the United States Attorney and the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today.

title: Carolyn Wyeth, Realist Artist, Dies at 84
description: Carolyn Wyeth, an artist and sister of the painter Andrew Wyeth, died on Tuesday at her home in Chadds Ford, Pa. She was 84.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday showing weapons the police said they found in the possession of a suspect in the shooting on the Brooklyn Bridge transposed photographs of two handguns in some editions. The Ruger pistol has a silver barrel, part of which is visible at the top; the Glock is all black.

title: Genovese Drug Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend in January 1994.

title: Saberhagen Shoulder A Worry On Day 1
description: Maybe the Mets want to trade Bret Saberhagen, and maybe they want him to be one of the top pitchers in their rotation. Either way, they couldn't have been happy with what happened this afternoon.

title: Israel Frees More Prisoners, But Arabs Are Not Mollified
description: Israel released hundreds more Palestinian prisoners today, but the gesture did little to defuse Arab rage and bitterness six days after the massacre of worshipers at a Hebron mosque.

title: Books of The Times; Detective Work, 400 Years Later
description: The Reckoning The Murder of Christopher Marlowe By Charles Nicholl Illustrated. 413 pages. Harcourt Brace & Company. $24.95.

title: Police Officer Fatally Shoots a Bronx Man
description: A police officer in the Bronx yesterday killed an emotionally disturbed man who had frightened his mother and her roommate, then attacked officers who responded to their 911 calls, the police said.

title: The Organization Man: Showalter Lives Details
description: Practice had been over for more than four hours. It was dark. The Yankees' spring training complex was empty, or so Buck Showalter thought. His work finally done, the Yankee manager decided to shower.

title: Israeli Curbs on Far-Right Settlers Provoke Only Scorn From Targets
description: Lenny Goldberg, one of six Jewish settlers here who are targets of Israel's announced get-tough policy against militants, slung his army-issue Uzi over his right shoulder today, the same weapon the Government says is supposed to be taken from him.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Intel Will Accelerate Drive For Acceptance of New Chip
description: The Intel Corporation will accelerate its drive to make the personal computer market rapidly accept its new generation of chips with the introduction on Monday of two faster versions of its Pentium microprocessor.

title: Fluor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Market Place; Ways for investors to hitch their stars to suppliers for electric cars.
description: SHOULD investors grab a ride aboard the embryonic electric vehicle industry?

title: The Feud That Froze Secaucus; Voided Election Leaves Town in Bureaucratic Limbo
description: Like the town he has served for 26 years, Philip J. Kieffer is a little edgy these days. He wants nothing more than to be left alone to his job as Secaucus' Chief Administrator, tapping away at his computer in soothing bureaucratic anonymity.

title: Toyota May Set U.S. Goals
description: The chairman of the Toyota Motor Corporation suggested today that his company would be willing to set voluntary goals for increasing its purchases of American-made automotive parts.

title: 50-Off Stores (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,404,000, or 33 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accouting change.c-Net incomeShare earnings and shares outstanding were fully diluted.(Loss)

title: Corrections
description: A brief report about best-seller lists in the Book Notes column on Wednesday misstated the number of categories in the lists published by The New York Times and their headings. There are six categories, three each in hard cover and in paperback. They are fiction; nonfiction; and advice, how-to and miscellaneous. The report also misstated the day on which faxes of the Times's lists become available; it is Thursday of the week in which they are compiled, not Wednesday.

title: When Arnold Schwarzenegger Made a Movie in Times Square; No Censorship for Koch
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Advanta Corp., is selling $174.5 million of certificates backed by home equity loans through Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch & Co. The issue is rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corp. * Federal Home Loan Bank, Washington, is selling $169 million of notes due in 1996 priced at 100 to yield 4.89 percent through J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. The issue is noncallable.

title: Canadian Imperial Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Belmont and Saratoga Plan Schedules and Changes
description: Racing in New York was shut down by wintry weather today for the 15th time in two months. But racing officials, taking the long view, announced a schedule of 41 stakes for the 67-day springtime meeting at Belmont Park plus some changes in the distance of races at the 34-day summertime meeting in Saratoga.

title: NBC Not Sharing Olympics in 1996
description: NBC has decided to go it alone without a cable partner -- either TNT, ESPN or the USA Network -- for the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta and is considering adding 15 to 20 hours of daytime Olympic programming.

title: The Iron Man of Congress Ends a Streak in Absentia
description: For the first time in 40 years, the voting light next to the name of Representative William H. Natcher remained dark today as the ailing Kentucky Democrat chose to stay in the hospital rather than repeat Wednesday's grim spectacle of being wheeled onto the House floor to vote from his gurney.

title: Father Requests Return to Israel For Boy in Religious Tug-of-War
description: The tangled struggle over a 15-year-old yeshiva student, Shai Fhima, grew more complex today when his father filed a petition asking that the youth be ordered to return to Israel with him.

title: Airwaves for Sale
description: The Clinton Administration has launched a landmark proposal to free up a major segment of the airwaves now largely reserved for the military -- an important step down the information superhighway. Over the next decade or so, the proposal will make a broad range of wireless telephone, video, audio and all other telecommunications services available for commercial use.

title: When Arnold Schwarzenegger Made a Movie in Times Square; The Hijacked Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 365602 -- No Title
description: New City Cafe, a charming little restaurant that serves stylish renditions of new American food, is not just a welcome addition to Brooklyn, it's welcome to all of New York. You would have difficulty finding in Manhattan what New City offers: fine food in a cozy, romantic setting, elegant presentation, white tablecloths, beautiful china, fresh flowers and cloth napkins, and all for a price that is tough to nudge above $20.

title: Record Price In a Sale of Art Owned By Streisand
description: Barbra Streisand's collection of Art Deco and Art Nouveau was auctioned by Christie's yesterday for $5.8 million, well above the $4 million the auction house estimated the sale would bring. More than a third of the total, $2 million, came from a single painting, Tamara de Lempicka's "Adam and Eve" from 1932, a record for a painting by that Art Deco artist and well above Christie's top estimate of $800,000. The purchase was made anonymously, and Christie's would not identify the buyer.

title: An idealistic promoter takes center stage in an effort to teach Broadway how to promote itself.
description: ADVERTISING executives who believe they face arduous assignments ought to consider what Susan Lee confronts.

title: A New Joint Test of Interactive TV
description: In the latest linkup of computing and communications giants, the Microsoft Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. said today that they had agreed to jointly test interactive cable television systems.

title: De-Icing at 'Outer Limit' On Jet Involved in Crash
description: The jet that skidded off a runway at La Guardia Airport on Wednesday, missing a plunge into Flushing Bay by four feet, had been de-iced once and had reached the "outer limit" of that treatment's effectiveness, a Federal aviation official said yesterday. But the official stopped short of saying that ice was suspected as the cause of the accident.

title: Metall Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 19 million on the sale of an investment for the quarter and year.c-Included a gain of $ 6.5 million on the sale of an investment for the quarter and year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Surpassing Predictions, Vehicle Sales Jump 19.8%
description: Automotive sales shot up 19.8 percent last month, compared with February of last year, exceeding even the optimistic expectations of industry executives, forecasters, retailers and Wall Street analysts.

title: Motive Described in Abortion Doctor's Death
description: The prosecution's final witness in the trial of a man charged with murder in an abortion doctor's death told the jury today that she had overheard the defendant admit killing the doctor "to save a baby."

title: Blackmun Tackles Question of Who Shall Die
description: To the Editor:

title: When Arnold Schwarzenegger Made a Movie in Times Square
description: To the Editor:

title: Tates Locke Dismissed
description: Indiana State's athletic committee yesterday recommended the dismissal of the basketball coach, TATES LOCKE, whose 4-22 record this season was the worst in his five years at the school. Athletic Director BRIAN FAISON had asked the committee to endorse his recommendation to release Locke.

title: Grand Jury Is Reportedly Told Of Shredding at Little Rock Firm
description: An employee of the Rose Law Firm here has told a Federal grand jury that in late January he was ordered to destroy a box of documents from the files of Vincent W. Foster Jr., the White House lawyer whose suicide is under investigation by an independent counsel.

title: Blackmun Tackles Question of Who Shall Die; Not 8th Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Property Tax Changes Are Urged To Help Preserve Northeast Forest
description: A regional commission examining ways to preserve the 26-million-acre forest of northern New York and New England called yesterday for changes in the way the property is taxed to help individual owners keep control of their land. But despite the urging of some conservationists, it did not recommend specific changes in forestry practices or major programs to set up natural preserves.

title: 15th Storm Brings Northeast's Misery to New Depths
description: In Manhattan, mostly, it was annoying -- again. In the rest of the Northeast, it was blustery, powdery and treacherous -- again.

title: Terror Made Easy
description: As the jury weighs the evidence in the trial of four men charged with bombing the World Trade Center, news of the verdict is eagerly awaited -- especially by terrorists considering the next attack.

title: Art in Review
description: Lyubov Popova Leonard Hutton Galleries 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through March 31

title: An Ancient Ritual and a Mother's Asylum Plea
description: In trying to deport Lydia Oluloro, the Federal Government has presented a simple case. A native of a tiny Nigerian village, Mrs. Oluloro came to Oregon in 1986 and lied when she said she would stay no longer than her one-year tourist visa allowed.

title: Getting to Top of Empire State: Opening the Way for Disabled
description: The disabled will finally be able to visit the site of King Kong's final stand.

title: No Headline
description: "If they think this is going to prevent other Baruch Goldsteins from going out there, they're very wrong." DAVID AXELROD, a Jewish settler in the West Bank. [ A10:6. ]

title: Vatican and Jordan Opening Ties
description: Less than two months after a recognition agreement between the Roman Catholic Church and Israel, the Vatican today announced the establishment of diplomatic ties with Jordan.

title: For Children
description: Woodbury Ski Area Route 47 Woodbury, Conn. (203) 263-2203; (203) 263-2213 Recommended ages: 4 and up

title: Reviews/ Film; Beware of Kin Bearing Birds of Prey
description: "Greedy," which has the makings of a gleefully malevolent family comedy, begins on a note of inspired wickedness. Members of the McTeague clan are making their slavish pilgrimage to the home of Uncle Joe (Kirk Douglas), the foxy old millionaire whose health is very much on their minds. Nobody likes Uncle Joe, but the McTeagues can agree on this much: they want his money. Bearing stuffed birds of prey (which the old man apparently loves) and shepherding children with names like Joette and Jolene, they will do anything to win their uncle's favor.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Tyson Opens Hostile Bid For Turkey Processor
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest poultry producer and processor, said yesterday that it was beginning a hostile takeover bid for WLR Foods Inc., the fourth-largest turkey processor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It will be the little engine that could -- with the help of LUCIANO PAVAROTTI. An engine that will take trains through the Channel Tunnel, the 31-mile link between Folkestone, England, and Calais, France, was named for the renowned tenor yesterday. And he was on hand to christen the first of the locomotives at the naming ceremony in Folkestone.

title: Russia Agrees to French U.N. Plan on Bosnia
description: In a surprise move widely seen as confirming Moscow's desire to play a constructive role in ending the Bosnian war, Russia has dropped its objection to a French plan for breaking the Serbian siege of Sarajevo and securing free access to three other encircled towns in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Actava Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,404,000, or 25 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.c-Net income; the year was after a benefit of $ 1,034,000, or 6 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.The sales increase for the latest year was primarily from the acquisition of Diversified Products Corp. in June 1993.(Loss)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AETNA LIFE AND CASUALTY CO., Hartford, will close four of its buildings in the city and move 1,500 workers to other sites in the Hartford area. LESLIE FAY COS. INC., New York, won bankruptcy court approval for the sale of the assets and trademarks of its Hue Inc. hosiery unit to Kayser-Roth Corp., New York, a hosiery manufacturer. Kayser-Roth will pay about $4.5 million for the rights to the Hue name and also acquire Hue's existing inventory for more than $2 million.

title: America's Scholarly Palestinian Raises Volume Against Arafat
description: When Edward W. Said, the writer, critic and literary scholar, decided to step down from the Palestinian parliament-in-exile three years ago, he did so in silence. Beset by illness and doubts about Yasir Arafat, whom he had supported for nearly 20 years, Mr. Said exited so quietly that even those who follow Middle Eastern politics hardly noticed.

title: U.N. Seeks More Troops to Keep the Peace in Bosnia
description: As gunfire and explosions rocked the short-lived truce in Sarajevo today, United Nations officials said they need more than 10,000 new peacekeeping troops to prevent more violations there and in other parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and urged the United States to begin contributing troops to the peacekeeping force.

title: As Farrakhan Groups Land Jobs From Government, Debate Grows
description: The four security guards sit serenely behind the plexiglass barrier in the barren lobby of the Flaghouse Courts housing project. They tell visitors to pass through a metal detector, show identification and name the residents they want to visit. Occasionally, one of the four -- all young blacks whose contract says they earn $11 an hour -- picks up a walkie talkie, zips up his blue jacket and leaves the booth to patrol the building's hallways and staircases.

title: AIDS Work at a Nation of Islam Clinic Is Questioned
description: Its $213,000 contract may not be the biggest awarded to a business affiliated with the Nation of Islam. But the money paid to the Abundant Life clinic here to treat AIDS patients may have drawn the most attention.

title: A Lineup Change At Warner-Lambert
description: The Warner-Lambert Company has begun to make expected changes in its agency lineup by dismissing Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York from its consumer brands account, advertising executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity said yesterday.

title: DELL COMPUTER CORP. (NMS)
description: Shares of the Dell Computer Corporation rose $2.125 yesterday even though its fourth-quarter earnings were down nearly 50 percent and it posted a loss for the year. Still, the results exceeded the estimates of most Wall Street analysts.

title: Making the Pain Go Away
description: Nothing is more maddening to a patient suffering from severe pain than the refusal of doctors to prescribe potent painkillers. The patient knows the suffering is unbearable and cries out for medication, but an insensitive or unknowing medical profession withholds adequate relief.

title: Art in Review
description: Lester Johnson Edward Thorp 103 Prince Street SoHo Through April 2

title: Anita Morris, 50, Actress in Theater And Movies, Dies
description: Anita Morris, an actress who was nominated for a 1982 Tony Award for her exuberant performance as a brassy redhead in black-lace body stocking in the musical "Nine," died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 50.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls Stay on the Skids Clyde Drexler scored 27 points and the Portland Trail Blazers continued Chicago's home woes, 115-96, last night.

title: Americans Lose Their Edge
description: Hans Trinkl, a soft-spoken, self-effacing Austrian who has been emerging from the shadows of his ski team, stepped boldly into the sunshine today with a victory in the World Cup downhill.

title: A Verdict Against Terror
description: New Yorkers and all Americans have reason to be satisfied with the successful prosecution of four men who bombed the World Trade Center a year ago. The Government has not supplied all the answers to this frightening act of terrorism. But yesterday's verdict demonstrates that authorities caught at least some of the culprits and delivered a compelling case for convicting them.

title: Accord Set On Ulcer Drugs
description: The Astra/Merck unit of Merck & Company announced plans this week to collaborate with Applied Microbiology Inc. to develop drugs aimed at killing bacteria shown to cause ulcers.

title: We Need Aid Leverage to Slow Nuclear Race; Too Late to Stop It
description: To the Editor:

title: Hebron Massacre Further Wounds Arafat's Image
description: A week after the massacre of Palestinian worshipers by an Israeli gunman, Yasir Arafat, plagued by mounting defections from his dispirited P.L.O. and widespread disillusionment over his efforts to promote peace, has become one of most reviled figures in the occupied territories.

title: Off the Wrist, Onto the Road: A Swatch on Wheels
description: For those urban drivers who spend hours searching for parking, looking longingly at spaces a couple of bumpers too short, relief may be just three years away. In 1997, a tiny vehicle, nicknamed the "Swatchmobile," is scheduled to hit the streets.

title: Village Super Market reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 22
description: b-Included $ 400,000, or 14 cents a share, gain for a change in accounting for income taxes.c-Included $ 1,022,000 net gain on sale of a store for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Risking a Trade War
description: President Clinton's decision to invoke a trade law provision that would enable him to impose tough sanctions against Japan if the Japanese fail to open their markets to American goods is unnecessary, dangerous and misguided.

title: Hofstra Triumph Keeps Van Breda Kolff Coaching
description: The senior Pat Cosgrove scored 20 points to lead a balanced Hofstra attack as the Flying Dutchmen defeated Chicago State, 86-77, today in the first round of the East Coast Conference tournament at the University of Buffalo.

title: Recycling Compliance Put at $100 Million
description: The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that it would cost New York City at least $100 million to comply with the requirements of the city's own recycling law, raising the gap in the next fiscal year's budget to $2.4 billion.

title: Woolworth Corp. reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 29
description: b-Included a pretax loss of $ 168 million, or an after-tax loss of $ 104 million, or 79 cents a share, from the pending disposition of the company's Woolco stores in Canada, for the quarter and year. The quarter also included a pretax credit of $ 145 million, or $ 89 million after tax, or 69 cents a share, for the reversal of the repositioning charge. The year also included a pretax charge of $ 630 million, or an adjusted after-tax repositioning charge of $ 391 million, or $ 2.97 a share.c-Net incomeYear-ago periods were comprised of 14 weeks for the quarter and 53 weeks for the year.(Loss)

title: Short-Sale Rule Permanent
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission made permanent this week a rule that prevents manipulative short sales of stocks shortly before an equity offering.

title: Towering Over the Abortion Foe's Trial: His Leader
description: Officially it is Michael F. Griffin who is on trial for the killing of a doctor outside an abortion clinic here a year ago this month. But looming over the case is the brooding figure of John Burt, a charismatic local anti-abortion leader who, Mr. Griffin's lawyers say, brainwashed their client and drove him to commit murder.

title: President Condemns Beijing; Christopher Visit Questioned
description: President Clinton condemned the detention by China of Wei Jingsheng, its most prominent dissident, and several others, and Administration officials said the detentions could change Secretary of State Warren Christopher's plans to visit China next week.

title: Marcus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-After an accounting benefit of $ 1,782,000, or 13 cents a share, for the adoption of FASB 109.

title: Hillary Clinton Seeks Balance In News Coverage of Violence
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that excessive news coverage of violence might be just as damaging to children as violence on television programs and in movies, and she urged journalists to strike a better balance.

title: For The Elderly, Yet Another Way to Tap Home Equity
description: Marvin Kells, 70, of Los Angeles, recently used the equity in his house to buy a lifetime annuity. A retired freelance film editor, he had little savings and just $500 a month in income from Social Security. His 40-year-old house had been payed off long ago but was in desperate need of repair.

title: Review/Dance; Eliot Feld On Trials Of the Trade
description: "Doghead & Godcatchers." That's what Eliot Feld calls his new ballet, which received its premiere at the Wednesday night performance of Feld Ballets/NY at the Joyce Theater.

title: Rodman Sits but Beefs
description: DENNIS RODMAN of the San Antonio Spurs missed last night's game with Utah to serve a one-game suspension and was fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for head-butting JOHN STOCKTON of the Utah Jazz on Wednesday night. Rodman protested his innocence, asking why the league was "always picking on me."(AP)

title: 'Manhood Training' at the Mosque: Hope, Discipline, Defiance
description: More than two dozen black men, many dressed in work boots and baggy slacks and a few in business suits with briefcases at their sides, recently climbed the steep concrete stairs to Muhammad's Mosque No. 7 in Harlem in search of two things the Nation of Islam promised they could find inside: brotherhood and proper direction.

title:
EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: A Warning;
Egyptian Militants Vow Attacks on Americans
description: Just hours after four Muslim militants were convicted of bombing the World Trade Center, some of their sympathizers here warned that the verdicts will ignite a wave of bloody revenge attacks against Americans across the Middle East and the West.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA AND TIME WARNER IN DEAL
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc. announced a three-year contract yesterday to supply as many as one million interactive cable converter boxes to Time Warner Cable. Initially, the company will supply 500,000 of the set-top boxes over two years. Financial terms were not released. Shares of Scientific-Atlanta closed up $3.50, to $31.125, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, where its 12 percent gain was one of the best of the day. Time Warner said it would deploy the 8600x analog terminal in many parts of the country served by the company. Time Warner Cable is the nation's second-largest cable television operator, serving more than seven million homes.

title: Proffitt's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-In anticipation of the merger with McRae's Inc., the company adopted changes in accounting for inventories from the direct cost method to the full cost method, and in accounting for store preopening costs. Without the effects of the accounting changes, net income would have been $ 1,505,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter, and $ 6,933,000, or 75 cents a share for the year.Proffitt's said that its latest fourth quarter results were negatively affected by lower-than-anticipated sales, higher-than-planned markdowns and the amortization of $ 1,159,000 of preopening costs.

title: Before You Take the Vegetarian Vow
description: To the Editor:

title: Brainwashing Defense In Anti-Abortion Killing
description: As the defense neared the close of its case, the man accused of killing an abortion doctor here last year broke down and wept today when a local anti-abortion leader, John Burt, described the burial of two dismembered fetuses recovered from a Dumpster.

title: Sports of The Times; He Doesn't Want to Be Like Mike
description: MIKE HUFF is not one to go around saying he wants to be like Mike.

title: New U.S. Pressure on Trade Doesn't Seem to Spur Japan
description: With the Clinton Administration turning up the heat against Japan, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa conceded today that he had not yet begun to enact the sweeping economic reforms his country needs but vowed "to insure that the Japanese market is open to the rest of the world."

title: Buffett Stake In Salomon Grows to 19%
description: Warren E. Buffett has bought more stock in Salomon Inc. and now controls 19 percent of the company's voting power.

title: Two Blazers Arrested
description: CLIFF ROBINSON and ROD STRICKLAND of the Portland Trail Blazers were arrested early yesterday after a pushing and shoving match with a truck driver in Chicago. The trouble apparently began with a minor traffic accident about 4 A.M., which led to an argument in a parking lot, said Lieut. PATRICK LOGAN of the Chicago Police.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL IN TALKS TO SELL PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITALS
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell about 51 of its 61 psychiatric hospitals to the Charter Medical Corporation. No definitive agreement has been reached, but Charter is reviewing operations at a number of the hospitals, National Medical said. National Medical had said it expected to sell its psychiatric hospitals by the end of its fiscal year in May. It took a charge of $287.3 million against earnings for the quarter that ended on Nov. 30. National Medical, based in Santa Monica, Calif., operates 46 acute care hospitals and related health care businesses. Charter Medical, based in Macon, Ga., operates 75 psychiatric hospitals in the United States and Europe. Shares of National Medical rose 87.5 cents, to $61.375, on the Big Board. Charter Medical shares rose yesterday by $1.50, to $24, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: 'Highlights in Jazz' Concert
description: Gerry Mulligan, and the Billy Taylor Trio are to be the featured performers in a concert on Thursday at 8 P.M. at the Pace Downtown Theater, 3 Spruce Street, lower Manhattan. The concert is part of the "Highlights in Jazz" series. Tickets are $15; $11.50 for students. Information: (212) 346-1715.

title: 10 CLINTON AIDES CALLED IN INQUIRY ON ARKANSAS S.&L.
description: Ten senior White House and Treasury Department officials were subpoenaed tonight for testimony and documents related to an inquiry into a failed Arkansas savings and loan with ties to President Clinton and his wife.

title: ROGERS IS JOINED BY SHAW IN MACLEAN HUNTER BID
description: Rogers Communications Inc., eliminating a possible rival suitor, said Shaw Communications Inc. had joined its hostile takeover bid for Maclean Hunter Ltd. Rogers said it had agreed with Shaw, which is based in Edmonton, Alberta, to swap some cable assets if the takeover succeeded. Rogers, based in Toronto, said it was negotiating with other cable operators and similar agreements could be announced shortly. Rogers last month made an offer of $2.8 billion (Canadian), or $2.07 billion (United States currency), for Maclean Hunter, also based in Toronto. Maclean Hunter has rejected the unsolicited bid.

title: Lost Daughter's Images Touch a Mother's Heart
description: ON Dec. 22, Claire Avery, 82, left her retirement home in Stuart, Fla., and came to New York City to visit her 57-year-old daughter. The elderly woman knew that Rose Avery had not been feeling well, but she was not prepared for what she saw when she arrived at Ludlow Street on the Lower East Side, where her only child had lived and painted for the last 20 years.

title: Triple Crown Jinx Strikes Again: Dehere Fractures Leg
description: The rocky road to the Kentucky Derby claimed its biggest casualty today. Dehere, the juvenile champion of last year and the early favorite to win the Derby, fractured a bone above his right hind ankle and was withdrawn from racing in the Triple Crown series and possibly beyond.

title: Sarah Patton Boyle Author and Rights Advocate, 87
description: Sarah Patton Boyle, an author who was active in civil rights matters, died on Feb. 20 at her home in Arlington, Va. She was 87.

title: Minority Council Members Assail Plans for Hospitals
description: The president of the municipal hospital system ran into a barrage of criticism from black and Hispanic members of the City Council yesterday as he defended the Giuliani administration's plan to reduce the scope of reconstruction at Kings County Hospital Center and to close a burn unit at Harlem Hospital.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC., Minneapolis, named William J. Cadogan, its president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman.

title: CHUBB PLANS TO REPURCHSE UP TO 5 MILLION SHARES
description: The Chubb Corporation, based in Warren, N.J., said yesterday that it would repurchase from time to time up to five million shares of its common stock, which is about 5.7 percent of its shares outstanding as of Dec. 31, 1993. It also said its quarterly dividend had been increased to 46 cents a share from 43 cents. The nation's 15th-largest property and casualty insurer said the dividend would be payable to shareholders of record on March 18. Chubb shares were up $1.125 yesterday, to $74.75, on the Big Board.

title: Tokyo Journal; Electronics District Hits Hard Times
description: In a nation where it is considered impolite to call attention to oneself, the Akihabara district stands out, with its neon lights, its signs painted hot pink and emerald green and its hundreds of garish discount stores and back-alley stalls bursting with gadgetry, from televisions the size of postage stamps to remote-control toilets that provide a spray of water in lieu of paper.

title: Weather Lifts Joblessness In New York and New Jersey
description: Dampened by winter storms, the overall unemployment rate for New York and New Jersey took a turn for the worse last month, while the rate for New York City improved, reflecting the growing strength of the city's economy.

title: Mary Hemingway, 76, Author of Cookbooks
description: Mary Moon Hemingway, an author of food-processor cookbooks and a former editor of Vogue, House & Garden and Bride's magazines, died yesterday at her home in Kittery Point, Me. She was 76.

title: Casino Magic (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included operations of the Biloxi casino since June 5, 1993.Year-ago periods included operations of the Bay Saint Louis casino since Oct. 1, 1992.

title: No Headline
description: This verdict should send a clear and unmistakable message that we will not tolerate terrorism in this country. - MARY JO WHITE, United States Attorney, on the World Trade Center conviction. [ 28:1. ]

title: Bonds Plunge but Then Improve
description: Prices of short- and intermediate-term Treasury securities were lower yesterday, but improved significantly from an early plunge after a larger-than-expected increase in the February nonfarm payroll data issued by the Labor Department.

title: Southwest Gas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-The company wrote off $ 15,886,000 in gross plant, which resulted in a noncash, after-tax reduction to 1993 net income of $ 9,264,000, or 44 cents a share.

title: Schools Suffering as Winter Plays Havoc With Calendar
description: In May, the students in Mirla Morrison's history class at Ossining High School are to take a national exam that could exempt them from studying history in their first year of college.

title: Perry Drug Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 2.4 million, or 20 cents a share, from sale of Chicago stores.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JUDY HENDREN MELLO has been named the president and chief executive of World Learning, formerly known as the Experiment in International Living.

title: Croatian Leader Backs Pact by Bosnia's Muslims and Croats
description: Breaking with the hard-line nationalists who have backed him in the past, President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia has endorsed a peace accord signed this week by Bosnia's Muslims and Croats and asserted that only people who hold "narrow-minded" or "extreme" views could oppose them.

title: Fewer Homes Finished
description: The pace of home and apartment construction fell in January, the Government said today. The number of homes completed declined 7.6 percent in January, to 1.193 million, the Commerce Department said. All regions of the country posted declines.
