description: Matthew E. Harlib, a producer and director of films and television, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan and Sherman, Conn.

title: A New Voice in Macy Case
description: A group of shareholders in R. H. Macy & Company is seeking a seat at the table where creditors are negotiating a plan of reorganization with the company.

title: 2d Hospital in Research Inquiry
description: St. Mary's Hospital, a community hospital in Montreal associated with McGill University, said today that a "discrepancy" had been found in one patient file it submitted as part of a major North American breast cancer study.

title: Albert Goldman, Biographer, Is Dead at 66
description: Albert Goldman, the author of no-holds-barred biographies of Lenny Bruce, Elvis Presley and John Lennon, died on Monday while traveling from Miami to London, where he was to take part in a television program on biography. He was 66 and lived in New York City.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Coach Johnson Is Unbeaten

title: South African Vote Official Optimistic Despite Killings
description: Downtown Johannesburg was in a state of nervous aftershock today from a rampage Monday through its hallowed commercial precincts. The Zulu homeland was writhing from the worst factional violence in many years.

title: Butterfinger Grabs Top Reggie Award
description: A promotion marketing campaign for Nestle's Butterfinger candy bar took top honors last night at the Promotion Marketing Association of America's annual Reggie Awards ceremony in Chicago.

title: ESPN and Prodigy Offering Sports Information Service
description: The ESPN sports television network and the Prodigy information network, the country's biggest players in cable television programming and on-line computer services, respectively, are teaming to create an interactive sports information service accessible through personal computers.

title: Sleeping With Parents May Benefit Infants
description: ALTHOUGH most parents are strongly advised to get their babies to sleep in their own cribs as soon as possible, a new study suggests that it may be healthier for the infants to sleep with their parents.

title: King Asserts Racial Taunt Is on Videotape
description: Rodney G. King, who has flip-flopped on whether the policemen who beat him in 1991 taunted him with racial epithets, offered a new assertion today: Not only did at least one of them shout a slur at him, but it can be heard on the much-scrutinized videotape of the beating.

title: Another Steep Drop For Stocks
description: For the stock market, the last four days of falling prices have been a sickening trip back in time. Yesterday's slide capped an eight-week decline that has wiped out most, if not all, of the gains this year.

title: Loft Grows To House 2 Dreams
description: BREAKFAST is over in the second-floor loft space at 151A North Third Street in Williamsburg and it is time for Olga Hiiva and her husband, Andy Teirstein, to go to work. Ms. Hiiva, who is 33 years old, kisses Mr. Teirstein and heads toward the southern part of the loft to work on her large oil paintings. Mr. Teirstein withdraws to an alcove in the northern corner, picks up a pencil and begins composing music.

title: John A. Burgess; Graphic Arts Executive, 63
description: John A. Burgess, president of the Graphic Arts Technical Foundation, a research and educational institute in Pittsburgh, died on Friday at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 63 and lived in Mount Lebanon, a suburb of Pittsburgh.

title: President Resigns at Limited Stores
description: Howard Gross, who struggled to no avail for three years to revive the beleaguered Limited stores, has resigned as president to join Today's Man, an off-price men's retailer, as president and chief operating officer.

title: For the Map-Challenged, Technology to the Rescue
description: Knitting together cellular phone technology and the Pentagon's navigation satellites, Nynex is testing a variety of high-technology services that would allow motorists to find out precisely where they are and how to get to their destination, even if they are completely lost and do not want to roll down a window to ask directions.

title: 'Mommies' Replace Madge for Palmolive
description: Three years after sending Madge the manicurist to advertising character heaven, the Colgate-Palmolive Company has doubled the number of spokeswomen to replace her in pitching its Palmolive dishwashing products line.

title: Kresse Staying Put
description: JOHN KRESSE, who led the College of Charleston to a 24-3 mark and its first appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament this season, agreed to a 10-year contract worth more than $900,000.

title: Merrill Agrees to Arbitrate
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has agreed to arbitrate claims by 60 investors who say they lost about $3 million in real estate limited partnerships in the 1980's.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LYNN REDGRAVE has been elected president of the Players, the 106-year-old club for actors and patrons of the arts, on Gramercy Park. Chosen for the post by the 22-member board of directors, she will be the Players' first female president. The first woman to be a member, Helen Hayes, was not admitted until 1988.

title: U.S. Spurns Japan's Concessions on Trade
description: The nation's top trade official dismissed Japan's latest proposed trade concessions today as inadequate and half-finished, and said the United States would not reopen trade talks until the Japanese went further.

title: Evolution Of Tea: Now It's Hip
description: TEA is becoming the coffee of the 90's. A new-found appreciation of fine tea has led to a rush of smart tea bars and tea shops from coast to coast.

title: Washington at Work; A Tax Lawyer Now Atop the I.R.S.
description: A year ago, just after President Clinton announced her nomination as Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Margaret Milner Richardson was toasted at lunch by friends, all female tax lawyers. Someone mentioned her legendary success as a fund-raiser for political causes and charities.

title: The Italian Right: 3 Men to Watch; Gianfranco Fini; National Alliance
description: In recent months Gianfranco Fini has been trying to shake off the past, distancing his neo-Fascist party from the blackshirts who led Italy to disaster in World War II.

title: Eating Well
description: ASK any parent to pick the most healthful beverage for a child, after milk, and the choice is most likely to be apple juice. It is seen as a clean, natural, fat-free beverage that is a healthy addition to a young child's diet. But a study published this month in the journal Pediatrics warns against too much of a good thing.

title: Ruling Allows DNA Testing As Evidence
description: The state's highest court ruled today that DNA testing, which can distill complex genetic codes from a spatter of blood or strands of hair, is reliable for identifying criminal suspects and can be admitted in court as evidence.

title: Market Place; Insurance investors still feel the rumbles from Los Angeles.
description: AFTERSHOCKS from the Los Angeles earthquake in mid-January have spread to Wall Street, where increases in the estimates of earthquake losses are raising questions about the long-term earnings prospects of large property insurance companies.

title: Action Was Preliminary On a Disputed Patent
description: The controversy over a sweepingly broad software patent may not be resolved, Federal patent officials and lawyers for the patent holder said today.

title: 2 Fire Companies Silently Mourn Two Who Fell in the Line of Duty
description: Engine Company 24 and Ladder Company 5 were out of service yesterday.

title: Met Roster Is Now 27; Olson Leads List of Cuts
description: After inheriting a disaster last summer, Dallas Green wanted nothing more than the opportunity to pick his own ball club. Today, Green got his chance.

title: Drug Makers Plan Genetics Research Deal
description: In a vote of confidence for the emerging drug-discovery science of genomics, Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. plans to enter a research collaboration agreement with Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. valued at more than $70 million.

title: William Golub, 79, Lawyer Specializing In Transport Issues
description: William W. Golub, a Manhattan lawyer who played a leading role in the renovation of public transportation in the New York metropolitan area in the 1950's, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giuliani Promises Firefighters New Gear
description: A day after a firefighter was killed when a wall of flame trapped him in a SoHo apartment building, and hours before a second firefighter died from burns suffered in the same blaze, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he would outfit the department in the kind of protective gear fire experts maintain could have prevented the deaths.

title: GENERAL MAGIC SAID TO BE PLANNING STOCK OFFERING
description: General Magic, a closely watched three-year-old company that makes software for hand-held computers, is planning to raise up to $45 million through an initial public offering by mid-May, The San Francisco Chronicle reported yesterday. Officials of the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., declined to comment on the plan, but the newspaper quoted people close to and inside General Magic as saying it planned to sell up to three million shares at $12 to $15 each in an offering underwritten by Goldman, Sachs & Company, Alex. Brown & Sons, and Smith Barney Shearson. Investors in General Magic include the technology giants Apple Computer Inc., Motorola Inc., the Sony Corporation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.

title: 'Sesame Street' Starts by Celebrating Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Evening Hours page of Styles of The Times on Sunday, about an opening at the American Crafts Museum, misidentified a woman shown. She was Janet Kardon, the museum director, not Kate Carmel.

title: 2 STATES TO JOIN IN SYSTEM TO STOP FRAUD IN WELFARE
description: Responding to reports of welfare recipients illegally collecting benefits in more than one state, New York and New Jersey have agreed to develop a system to compare their welfare rolls in an effort to weed out millions of dollars in fraud.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding have been retroactively adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock dividends declared in April and December 1993.

title: Brodeur Sets a Record For Victories by Goalie
description: From Martin Brodeur in goal to the last player on the fourth line, the Devils played one of their best games of the season tonight. They had to in order to achieve a 5-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens, last season's Stanley Cup champions, and to keep pace with the Rangers, who are intent on becoming this season's Stanley Cup champions.

title: Daly Out With Flu and Nets Are Out of Steam at Atlanta
description: Because the Atlanta Hawks and Nets came into their game tonight in second and seventh place, respectively, in the Eastern Conference playoff standing, the match up was hyped as a playoff preview.

title: Maas Sees a Silver Lining in His Release
description: Kevin Maas shook hands, collected some bats, stared at the pinstriped uniform hanging in his locker one final time, smiled at his wife and smiled at the world. His eight-year association with the Yankees came to its expected demise today when he was released. Maas was excited. Reality will probably hit later.

title: Review/Film Festival; Growing Up Ever at War
description: "Little Dreams," an earnest but inept Egyptian film rounding out the geographical range of this year's New Directors/New Films series, observes the 1967 war between Egypt and Israel through the eyes of a young Egyptian boy. Ghareeb (Tamer Ashraf), who is only 13 at the time of the film's climactic events, has already seen his short life greatly influenced by war. His father died in the Suez war of 1956. The boy's destiny is shaped by memories of a man he barely knew.

title: Jury Finds Mercer Is Not Guilty In Ferguson Bout Bribery Case
description: Winning the most important unanimous decision of his heavyweight career, Ray Mercer was found not guilty of sports bribery yesterday.

title: Man Dies in Custody
description: A man who struggled with a police officer and two others lost consciousness and died about 6:30 P.M. yesterday, the police said. The man, who was not immediately identified, had been seen "dragging" his 2-year-old son down a street in Flatbush, Brooklyn, the police said. Two men intervened and called the authorities, and they and a police officer took the child away from the man. He struggled to take the child back, then collapsed and was taken to Kings County Hospital, where he died, the police said.

title: U.S. Halts Recruitment of Cancer Patients For Studies, Pointing to Flaws in Oversight
description: Federal officials at the National Cancer Institute yesterday took sweeping action intended to correct serious deficiencies of oversight in several large studies being carried out at the University of Pittsburgh to determine new standards of care for cancer patients.

title: Man In the News: Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon; A Tragedy's Stand-In
description: Two years ago, when he was Secretary of Education, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon tried to set Mexican history straight by ordering new public-school textbooks that for the first time mentioned student demonstrations in 1968 and seemed to blame the Mexican Army for shooting protesters.

title: A Cultural Capital Tries to Live Up to Its Label
description: Every year since Melina Mercouri, as the Greek Minister of Culture, thought up the idea more than a decade ago, a city has been outfitted with the trappings of Cultural Capital of Europe. But as earnest aficionados trekked about Europe from one such capital to the next, they began to wonder how much of this program was truly cultural and how much half-baked touristic promotion.

title: Safety Gear for Firefighters
description: Mayor Giuliani said he would outfit firefighters in new gear that experts said might have saved the lives of two firefighters. Page B2.

title: Dream Team II Is Set
description: SHAQUILLE O'NEAL of the Orlando Magic and REGGIE MILLER of the Indiana Pacers will be the final two players on Dream Team II, which will represent the United States in the world basketball championships this summer in Toronto.

title: Sports of The Times; Cowboys' Cozy Couple Splits
description: YOU probably know a couple just like them. As soon as their divorce was final, as soon as the financial settlement had been agreed upon, they couldn't say enough nice things about each other. And yesterday the latest cozy couple to fit that description sat side by side in front of a blue-and-silver Cowboys banner.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: East Meets West

title: Blenheim Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Pretaxc-Included $ 17.6 million charge, including goodwill of $ 15 million, for loss on termination of operations of interests in Belgium and Switzerland.Year-ago period was on a pro-forma basis to give effect to change in foreign exchange policy for translating overseas profits and losses.

title: Hillary Clinton Turned $1,000 Into $99,540, White House Says
description: The White House said today that in 1978 Hillary Rodham Clinton invested $1,000 in commodities futures and that the investment grew in 10 months of trading in the notoriously volatile market into a gain of nearly $100,000.

title: Wine Talk
description: IF there were a perfect wine grape -- there isn't, of course -- it would be the chardonnay.

title: Prudential Deadline May Change
description: Lawyers for plaintiffs in the largest class-action suit stemming from Prudential Securities' limited partnership scandal will support extending the amount of time that investors have for withdrawing from the settlement of that case, regulators said yesterday.

title: Bridge Column
description: The Bridge column now appears on Mondays, Thursdays and Saturdays. The location is shown at the bottom of the News Summary on page 2 of the first section.

title: Bronx Couple Charged With Murder in the Death of Their Daughter, 4
description: To friends and neighbors, Orlando and Sherain Bryant appeared to be attentive, well-meaning parents who frequently walked their five children to school and to church every Sunday. But the police say the Bryants were regularly beating and abusing their children, finally killing 4-year-old Shayne Bryant on Monday.

title: The Italian Right: 3 Men to Watch; Silvio Berlusconi; Forza Italia
description: Last fall the media magnate Silvio Berlusconi set up 1,200 political clubs across Italy to improve the chances of centrist parties against the powerful former Communists. Linked by computer, the groups were modeled after fan clubs of the soccer team he owns in Milan.

title: Japan Makes It Tough to Do Business There
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. May Give Lorenzo Airline a 2d Chance
description: Citing "an effort to avoid the appearance of bias or partiality,' the Department of Transportation offered today to conduct a new hearing on whether ATX Inc., a company with ties to Frank Lorenzo, is fit to operate an airline.

title: Book Notes
description: The mention made Mr. Epstein cringe, he recalled last week: Here was another aspiring writer with some egregious novel. But when he read the beginnings of the novel in translation, he said, he found it riveting. "Absolution" has just been published by Pantheon, a division of Random House, with a first printing of 10,000, a respectable number for a literary novel from abroad. The book is about an embittered Icelandic expatriate who has been harboring a guilty secret for decades. It hasn't been widely reviewed, but The New York Times Book Review said it was "unexpectedly enjoyable," and Entertainment Weekly gave it an A.

title: Review/Film; The Great, Big Worries of Such a Tiny Girl
description: If there is an underlying message in Don Bluth's animated musical, "Hans Christian Andersen's 'Thumbelina,' " it is that nice little girls with big dreams should stay as far away from show business as possible. The parade of characters who try to manipulate and possess Thumbelina (Jodi Benson), a tiny 16-year-old girl who springs magically from the center of a flower, are a rogue's gallery of unwholesome show-business types. When not ogling and pawing the thumb-size girl, they promise her a grubby, compromised notoriety on the lower rungs of the show-business ladder.

title: H. S. Strygler, 75, Importer and Donor
description: Harry S. Strygler, a pearl importer and philanthropist, died on Sunday at the Hilton Hotel in Rye, N.Y., where his family was celebrating Passover. He was 75.

title: McCaffrey a Player With a Mission
description: Billy McCaffrey has a world of things to smile about. He has back-to-back seasons of averaging 20 points a game -- 20.9 this season -- making him the first Vanderbilt basketball player to do that since 1966.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FIREFIGHTERS MOURN A FALLEN COMRADE

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cigarette Giants Switch From Fantasy to Empathy
description: Reality is riding into Marlboro country.

title: Rightist Victors in Italian Vote Continue Battle for Real Power
description: Less than a day after surging to an election victory, the right-wing alliance led by the media magnate Silvio Berlusconi became enmeshed in a power struggle today that threatened its ability to form a strong government.

title: Commercial Fisheries Evade Conservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Cambodians Traveled to Study and Stayed to Cook
description: AS one drives along Anaheim Street in this dowdy port 25 miles south of downtown Los Angeles, past liquor stores, auto body shops and shopping centers, signs suddenly sprout wiggly Khmer script. This area is "Little Phnom Penh," a mile-long corridor that is the center of the world's largest Cambodian expatriate community, with temples and video stores, markets and restaurants.

title: Edwards (A.G.) Inc.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share net reflected 5-for-4 stock split paid Jan. 3, 1994.

title: People
description: * Ron Pantello, chairman and chief executive at Lally, McFarland & Pantello, New York, and Ed Tedeschi, a partner at Lally's sibling agency, Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG, New York, were named to jointly oversee a new venture specializing in consumer health care communications, called Messner/LM& P. The unit will seek projects from existing clients of the two agencies, which are both owned by Euro RSCG, as well as solicit new accounts. * Samuel D. Ostrow, president of the public affairs division of the Rowland Co. U.S., New York, was named to the new position of international director at Rowland Worldwide, New York, responsible for its global liability management activities.

title: Why So Many Die Needlessly: Broken Cardiac Rescue Chain
description: THROUGHOUT the United States, and especially in big cities and rural areas, tens of thousands of people with hearts that should be good enough to keep them alive die each year for lack of adequate first aid. In New York City, for example, a new study has shown that only one person in 100 outside of hospitals survives after the heart suddenly stops pumping. In contrast, in Seattle the survival rate after such cardiac arrests is 1 in 5.

title: Breakup of Cowboys' Team Leaves a League in Wonder
description: Pro football's coaches, players, broadcasters and agents expressed shock and surprise at the resignation of Coach Jimmy Johnson yesterday. They saw potential problems for the Dallas Cowboys next season.

title: Gaza Killings Leave Peace Caught in a Crossfire
description: To Salah Abu Eida, who saw the shooting, it was an execution.

title: Books of The Times; Disturbing Childhoods And Their Aftereffects
description: The Favourite By Meredith Daneman 163 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19. Now You See Her By Whitney Otto 303 pages. Villard. $20.

title: Accounts
description: * NFL Enterprises, New York, to Margeotes Fertitta Donaher & Weiss, New York, as the first agency to handle its satellite subscription television service. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Cellstar Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Pro forma net was $ 1,681,000, or 9 cents a share, adjusted for chief executive's new employment agreement, discontinuance of fees paid to Audiovox Corp., discontinuance of interest expenses resulting from the payment of notes payable to stockholders, and increase in income taxes due to these reduced expenses.

title: Britain Yields on Europe Union Dispute, Drawing Fire at Home
description: Britain gave ground today in a bitter dispute with the rest of Europe, paving the way for the European Union to grow from 12 countries to 16 by admitting three Scandinavian countries and Austria next January.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BAKER PERFORMANCE CHEMICALS INC., Houston, a unit of Baker Hughes Inc., announced that it would divest itself of its Mineral Handling Group, which markets dust suppressants and freeze conditioning agents to the coal mining and mineral transportation industry. MERCANTILE BANKSHARES CORP., Baltimore, has agreed to acquire Fredericksburg National Bancorp, Fredericksburg, Va., in a stock swap valued at $42.5 million.

title: Caterpillar
description: Cyclical stocks, ones that are thought to benefit from a resurgent economy, have been favorites among institutional investors all year. One of the most favored is Caterpillar Inc., the maker of tractors and other construction equipment. Caterpillar has risen strongly in 1994, gaining 24 percent, despite four consecutive price drops recently.

title: The Italian Right: 3 Men to Watch; Umberto Bossi; Northern League
description: A blunt 52-year-old politician from the economically vibrant Lombardy region, Umberto Bossi is the leader of a movement that caught the wind of taxpayer revolt when the first signs of recession appeared in the 1980's. Resentment was most acute among prosperous northern Italians, who felt that their pockets were being picked by the Government in Rome for pork-barrel projects in the depressed south.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of an article about violence in Johannesburg referred incorrectly in some editions to the police officers shown taking cover from gunfire. They were uniformed officers, not plainclothes.

title: Settler Tells of Call by Hebron Killer's Wife
description: A Jewish settler said today that minutes before the Hebron massacre, the wife of the killer had contacted him looking for her husband and saying he had not gone to the Cave of the Patriarchs shrine to pray.

title: Florida Is Back, Doing It Right
description: The black letters posted above the front doors of the Florida Bookstore practically shouted down University Avenue with news the people had been clamoring for since that instant on Sunday afternoon when the street was flooded with Gators, automobiles, bicycles and joy.

title: Court Confronting Results of Limiting Death Row Appeals
description: In a death penalty argument marked by tense exchanges and an unusual display of anger from the bench, the Supreme Court came face to face today with the implications of its recent rulings sharply limiting the access of state death-row inmates to Federal court.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 NEW NOMINEE IN MEXICO Mexico's governing party selected a 42-year-old former Cabinet minister and economist as its new presidential nominee, a week after the assassination of the heavily favored candidate of the party. A1 For the new candidate, a delicate balancing act. A6

title: Caution by Mutual Fund Investors
description: With interest rates rising and stock prices dropping, mutual fund investors are showing more caution than they have in years, fund managers said yesterday. But stock funds still appear to be taking in more cash from new investments than they are losing to redemptions.

title: Isles Turn Powerless In Race for Playoffs
description: The Islanders may well miss the playoffs this year, and if they do, they might have only themselves and a late-season scoring drought to blame for it.

title: Pepsi-Cola to Stamp Dates For Freshness on Soda Cans
description: For decades, marketers have managed to convince American consumers that they had problems they never knew were problems -- halitosis, body odor, coffee nerves, dishpan hands, even bad breath in dogs -- and then peddle them solutions.

title: Health Plans Promise Choice But Decisions May Be Hard
description: As the White House and Congress debate the best way to reshape the nation's health system, an overriding concern remains: What effect will the final plan have on the quality of care Americans receive?

title: INTEL AND PACIFIC BELL SIGN VIDEO CONFERENCING PACT
description: The Intel Corporation and Pacific Bell signed an agreement yesterday on computer-based video conferencing in California. Under the agreement, Intel's Proshare Video System 200 products will be available from resellers for $999 when an integrated services digital network, or I.S.D.N., line is ordered from Pacific Bell, the companies said. An I.S.D.N. line enables the transmission of data, facsimile, and video signals across a network. The Proshare Video System 200 uses a tiny camera and add-on cards to enable personal computers based on Intel's 486 or Pentium chips to exchange live video. Pacific Bell said more than 60 percent of its telephone lines in California have access to I.S.D.N. technology.

title: Chief of Staff To Salinas Resigns Post
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's powerful chief of staff resigned his post suddenly tonight. The official, Jose Cordoba Montoya, was an architect of Mr. Salinas's economic reform policies and a political mentor to the governing party's new presidential candidate.

title: Giuliani and City Union Chiefs Agree on a Plan to Reduce Jobs
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the municipal labor unions announced last night that they had reached an agreement on a package of severance offers that the Mayor hopes will cut 7,600 jobs from New York City's payroll without having to resort to layoffs.

title: Arkansas Coach Sees Beyond Final Four
description: The Arkansas Razorbacks will leave for Charlotte, N.C., Thursday morning and plunge into the hoopla of the Final Four weekend.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Camellia Johnson Soprano 92d Street Y

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN Dr. Richard M. Lerner was 15, he told his parents that he couldn't live with them anymore. He moved in with his grandmother, who lived in another neighborhood in Brooklyn. The adults stayed in close touch. Three weeks later, tired of the long commute to his high school and in need of fresh clothes, he returned home.

title: Steven R. Kohn; Professor, 51
description: Dr. Steven R. Kohn, professor of dermatology at the Yale University School of Medicine, died on March 23 at his home in Guilford, Conn. He was 51.

title: From Northrop, a One-Day-Only Grumman Offer
description: Borrowing a page from hard-sell television merchandising, Kent Kresa, chief executive of the Northrop Corporation, offered a $70 million premium for the Grumman Corporation today, but only if it agreed to a merger offer within 24 hours.

title: Chamber Music Society To Present Premieres
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to present the world premieres of works by Ned Rorem, Joan Tower and Wynton Marsalis, and the New York premieres of pieces by Andre Previn, John Harbison and Osvaldo Golijov as part of its 26th season.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Carmina Quartet Walter Reade Theater

title: Placing Heaven on Earth for the World of 'Carousel'
description: Two years ago, Nicholas Hytner and Bob Crowley, an English director and an Irish set designer, flew to the United States and toured the Maine seacoast in a rented car. They spent four or five days visiting the region's ocean-front villages, taking in the prim white churches, the trim lawns, the beaches and the sea and listening, not incidentally, to "Carousel" on the tape deck.

title: Small Nuclear Arsenal Is Defense Dept. Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: "I missed football. I don't know how this happened. I thought my time had passed." -- BARRY SWITZER, new coach of the Dallas Cowboys. [ B11:2. ]

title: Schnitzer Steel Ind.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Dance Notes
description: Group Downsizes Itself

title: Bye-Bye to Balboni
description: STEVE BALBONI, a member of the 1985 World Series champion Kansas City Royals, was among six players cut yesterday by the team. Balboni, at 37 years old trying to make it back to the major leagues after spending almost all of the last three seasons in the minors, said he was retiring from baseball. (AP)

title: B.C. Hires Milbury
description: Tired of contract negotiations and his other duties as a National Hockey League assistant general manager, MIKE MILBURY left the Boston Bruins yesterday to become hockey coach at Boston College. Milbury, 41, went from star defenseman to coach of a Stanley Cup finalist to assistant general manager during a 20-year career with the Bruins. (AP)

title: Devils Lose Daneyko In the Heat of a Battle
description: How the Devils will adjust to the loss of Ken Daneyko in their battle with the Rangers for the top spot in the National Hockey League is the question now hanging over New Jersey.

title: A Settlement by Salomon
description: Salomon Inc. said yesterday that it had settled the remaining class-action lawsuits from the 1991 Treasury auction scandal for $66 million.

title: Gillen to Providence
description: PETE GILLEN switched coaching jobs yesterday, leaving Xavier of Ohio for Providence. Gillen replaced RICK BARNES, who left Providence last week to take the job at Clemson. Gillen, 46, coached at Xavier since the 1985-86 season. (AP)

title: Avis Chief Sees Big Challenge at UAL
description: Joseph V. Vittoria, the chairman and chief executive of Avis Inc., had never accepted an offer to serve on another company's board. "I've got plenty to do at my own company," he said.

title: J. Hobart Warner; Dean, 85
description: J. Hobart Warner, a dean and faculty member of the Wooster School in Danbury, Conn., for 44 years, died Monday at the Genesee Hospital in Rochester. Mr. Warner, who had moved to Rochester last year, was 85.

title: Depositors to Withdraw Money in Retaliation for Natwest Bank's Transfer of Jobs
description: Venting frustration over another exodus of jobs from Long Island, several local government officials and real-estate developers said yesterday that they would withdraw money from National Westminster Bank to protest a transfer of some back office operations to Pennsylvania.

title: Doc's Fine But He's Not Sure About Mets
description: Dwight Gooden is pleased with his pitching. He is pleased with his health. And he was pleased with his performance today in his final start of the spring.

title: Bank to Merge 2 Operations
description: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, in an effort to hold onto and bring back some large corporate clients, said today that it would merge its corporate loans and brokerage operations.

title: Sharp Increase Along the Borders of Poverty
description: The Census Bureau provided new evidence today of one of the most troubling trends in the American economy: a sharp increase in the percentage of people who work full-time but cannot by themselves lift a family out of poverty.

title: Carillon Importers Selects Margeotes
description: Carillon Importers Ltd. said yesterday that it had selected Margeotes Fertitta Donaher & Weiss in New York to handle the account of several brands for which it recently acquired distribution rights, including Stolichnaya vodka. The brands, with billings estimated at $10 million, had been handled by Calet, Hirsch & Ferrell, now Ferrell Calvillo, in New York, for more than a decade.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Alltel Corp., Little Rock, Ark., is selling $250 million of 7.25 percent notes due in 2004 at 99.508 to yield 7.32 percent through Stephens Inc. The noncallable issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Rahat Journal; After Hebron, a Fierce Test of Bedouin Loyalty
description: In this Bedouin town on the northern lip of the Negev, not an Israeli flag was to be seen today.

title: Article 629650 -- No Title
description: Ten arts organizations in New York State are to receive $3.02 million in challenge grants from the National Endowment for the Arts. The grants, which range from $75,000 to $800,000, are among $13.12 million in grants being made this year by the endowment. To receive the grants, organizations must match each Federal dollar with $3 from other donations.

title: Economic Scene; A challenge to the complacent on the U.S. unemployment rate.
description: AS you have heard before and will no doubt hear again, it's America's turn to gloat. The economy is perking along nicely, while unemployment is at its lowest point in three years and still heading south. Japan and Europe, by contrast, remain mired in recession.

title: Critic's Notebook; Old Jazz Is Out, New Jazz Is Older
description: The presentation of a new work by the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall will undoubtedly reignite the critical furor that has hounded the Lincoln Center jazz program for the last few years. Mr. Marsalis is the program's artistic director, and critics, commentators and some older musicians of an experimental bent (though not audiences, which flock to the concerts) have been complaining with great regularity about the preponderance of Mr. Marsalis's own band members in the program's shows, and the yearly presentation of a new commission to himself.

title: William H. Natcher Dies at 84; Held Voting Record in Congress
description: Representative William Huston Natcher, a Kentucky Democrat whose political longevity and spotless reputation won him the most powerful committee post in the House, died of heart failure late Tuesday. He was 84.

title: Williams Is Willing; Yanks Are Cautious
description: Bernie Williams thinks that he will be healthy enough to play center field when the Yankees open their season on Monday against the Texas Rangers, but his opinion is probably irrelevant. The officials who make that decision will wait at least another day and possibly longer before announcing anything definitive.

title: U.S. ENDING CURBS ON HIGH-TECH GEAR TO COLD WAR FOES
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it was scrapping virtually all export controls imposed during the cold war on shipments of telecommunications equipment and computers to China, and to Russia and most other former Soviet bloc countries. The move is expected to open a market worth roughly $150 billion over the next decade.

title: Skull in Ethiopia Is Linked to Earliest Man
description: The first reasonably complete skull of the earliest recognized human ancestors after the split-off from the great apes has been found near the bank of a dry riverbed in Ethiopia's arid badlands.

title: Mother in Child Death Case Lost Custody Twice
description: Sherain Bryant, who was charged Tuesday with murdering her 4-year-old daughter Shayne, twice lost custody of her children to New York City child protection authorities because she abused cocaine, individuals familiar with court and child welfare records said yesterday.

title: Fears and Fanfare for the New Store in Town; A Giant Retailer Opens Its Doors, and Main Street Will Never Be the Same
description: When Mike Nero was 13, one of his favorite things to do was to drive his father's 1953 Ford station wagon around an uncleared field off Fairview Avenue in this rural Hudson Valley town. That was 30 years ago.

title: Democracy Postponed
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico had to wage a tough struggle to impose his choice of Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon as his party's new presidential candidate. For Americans as for Mexicans, Mr. Salinas's victory is a mixed blessing.

title: Albany Deal on Prison
description: Seeking to reduce prison crowding, Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders in Albany agreed on a $44 million plan to convert a state psychiatric hospital to a 750-bed prison, the first expansion for the correctional system since 1991. The agreement, which resolves the key issue of criminal-justice spending this year, would also create 500 beds for defendants and parolees who are addicts.

title: Magadan Goes on D.L.
description: Florida Marlins third baseman DAVE MAGADAN was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with a sprained right wrist, which means he will miss the first seven games of the season. Magadan is eligible to return for Florida's second home game April 13. The infielder hurt his wrist last week and aggravated the injury swinging a bat Monday. (AP)

title: STOCKS PLUMMET IN HEAVY TRADING
description: In a day that tested the faith of the remaining optimists on Wall Street, the stock market fell in heavy trading yesterday for the fifth consecutive session, with some traders predicting worse days ahead.

title: Latvians Resent Russian Troops Who Stay On; Death by Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: Rates Move Higher for a Second Day
description: Interest rates moved higher yesterday for the second straight session on investor fears of fast economic expansion and Federal Reserve monetary policy, as well as on end-of-quarter window-dressing by fund managers.

title: Homing In on Agenda While Clinton's Away
description: As President Clinton vacations in California this week, the aides he left behind are taking advantage of the lull created by his absence and the Congressional recess to try to rescue a domestic agenda knocked askew by Whitewater.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO., New York, said it would repurchase up to four million shares of its common stock in the open market. MONTGOMERY WARD & CO., , Chicago, the privately held retailer, completed the purchase of houseware retailer Lechmere Corp., for $100 million.

title: I.R.A. Plans 72-Hour Cease-Fire in Ulster
description: In its first conciliatory response to the British-Irish peace initiative of last December, the Irish Republican Army said tonight that it would observe a 72-hour cease-fire in Northern Ireland next week.

title: Vivra Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 697,000, or 3 cents a share, in the latest first quarter and $ 84,000 in year-ago period.Per-share figures reflected a 3-for-2 stock split in November.

title: Review/Theater; Another Chorus in the Ballad of John and Yoko
description: Although John Lennon's name is never mentioned in Yoko Ono's musical, "New York Rock," the show is really the latest chapter in Ms. Ono's continuing eulogy of her relationship with the slain rock star. In this version of the myth of the perfect couple separated by tragedy, an emotionally wounded but still idealistic pair named Jill and Bill (Lynnette Perry and Pat McRoberts) are the stand-ins for the Lennons.

title: 3 Utility Employees Hurt in Blast at a Power Substation
description: A transformer at a power station here exploded this morning in a deafening fireball, critically injuring three workers, knocking out electricity to nearly 30,000 customers in Hudson County for more than an hour and disrupting traffic and train service.

title: Review/Dance; Showing Off A Rare Gift: Scampering
description: The years have burnished and honed Nina Watt's gifts as a performer. Miss Watt, a senior member of the Limon Dance Company, is now a stunning example of how a fine dancer can grow into an artist. And the fruits of that process were much in evidence in a program presented by the company at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, when Miss Watt performed "Hollow Lady," a solo created for her by Alwin Nikolais.

title: Council Nominates 4 Areas For Economic Development
description: The City Council yesterday proposed establishing four new economic development zones in New York City, which would provide the distressed areas with state help to stimulate business and employment.

title: Weill Paid $26.4 Million
description: Travelers Inc. said today that it had paid Sanford I. Weill, its chairman and chief executive, $26.4 million last year.

title: All It Takes Is a Computer and Photos
description: "HEY, you never know," as the advertisements say, what fantasy scenes the New York State Lottery is cooking up to lure the public into buying chances for its multimillion-dollar Lotto jackpot.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A House for Life, Love, Art and New Inspiration
description: NESTLED in a fold of gently curving Sussex hills some 55 miles south of London is a rambling old dwelling typical of the area, made of flint and rendered brickwork, with parts dating to the 16th century. The timeless peace of its setting, however, and its serene facade belie the riotous interior. For more than 60 years, until the late 1970's, this was the home of Clive and Vanessa Bell and Duncan Grant, a haven where their passions for painting, writing and the decorative arts could be indulged, undisturbed.

title: Buying Used Fitness Gear
description: FOR many people, the impulse to get in shape is followed by a second impulse, and then a third: the desire to own home exercise equipment and a desire to avoid breaking the bank when buying it.

title: The Intricate Steps to Cutting the United Way Pie
description: Raising money for United Way takes ingenuity. So does spending it.

title: Warner's Daly-Semel Team Is Now Official
description: Robert A. Daly, the chairman and chief executive at Warner Brothers, said with a laugh today: "What makes Warner Brothers work isn't just Bob Daly. No way. It's Terry Semel, too."

title: SPANISH BANK RAISES STAKE IN FIRST FIDELITY TO 22.7%
description: Banco Santander S.A. of Spain has raised its stake in First Fidelity Bancorporation to 22.7 percent, from 20.1 percent, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The bank acquired 2.37 million shares of First Fidelity on March 29 by exercising warrants to buy stock at $25.50 a share, according to the filing. Banco Santander paid a total of $60.5 million in cash for the shares in First Fidelity, a bank holding company based in Lawrenceville, N.J., that has $33.8 billion in assets. In 1991, Banco Santander acquired 9.5 million shares and warrants to purchase an additional 9.5 million shares from First Fidelity.

title: The Honor Of Your Presence
description: OF all her customers at the Purgatory Pie Press, Esther K. Smith finds that brides-to-be are the most on edge. "They sort of go temporarily insane, in a positive way," said Ms. Smith, who runs the shop in lower Manhattan with her husband, Dikko Faust.

title: Koor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included nonrecurring income of $ 52 million.Results in U.S. dollars have been translated from Israeli shekels.

title: U.S. Renews Pledge to Aid Bosnia's Recovery After Peace Pact
description: The United States has pledged $10 million toward Sarajevo's reconstruction, but will not send troops here until after a settlement is reached to end the Bosnian war, the American representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, said here today.

title: Is It the Message or the Messengers?
description: Patrick Ewing is trading his brand-name basketball shoes for guns. The shoes retail for about $90. It is a deal you will not find on the Home Shopping Network.

title: Yanks Say No to Gay Games
description: The Yankees have denied Gay Games IV organizers the use of Yankee Stadium for their closing ceremonies on June 25, citing concerns about thousands of athletes marching on the field.

title: Mets Trade Young and Plug a Hole
description: The Mets purged themselves of the most vivid symbol of their woeful 1993 campaign today when they traded pitcher Anthony Young to the Chicago Cubs for Jose Vizcaino, who instantly supplanted the rookie Fernando Vina as New York's everyday shortstop and leadoff hitter. The Cubs also received Ottis Smith, a minor league pitcher, in the deal.

title: Morrison Restaurants Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 5
description: b-After a charge of $ 2,579,000, or 7 cents a share, from the adoption of FASB 106, accounting for postretirement benefits, and a benefit of $ 2,395,000, or 6 cents a share, from the adoption of FASB 109, accounting for income taxes.

title: U.S. to Press North Korea Over A-Sites
description: The United States has decided to press for a United Nations resolution demanding that North Korea open up its nuclear sites to international monitors despite objections from China, American officials said today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side rules are suspended today through Sunday because of religious holidays.

title: Texas Looks to Oklahoma: Cowboys Hire Switzer
description: Swiftly, decisively, and not so unexpectedly, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, filled his day-old head-coaching vacancy yesterday by naming Barry Switzer to replace Jimmy Johnson.

title: Capriati an Alternate
description: The four-woman team, plus a blockbuster alternate, that will represent the United States in Federation Cup competition July 18-24 in Frankfurt was announced yesterday in Hilton Head, S.C., by MARTY RIESSEN, who also captains the women's Olympic squad. JENNIFER CAPRIATI, absent from the WTA Tour since August, celebrated her 18th birthday Tuesday by confirming that she will be a Federation Cup alternate this summer. The 15th-ranked Capriati, who played on the 1990 championship team, is expected to return to competition this summer after taking time off to complete high school and rekindle her affection for her sport.

title: Mark IV Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After total extraordinary charges of $ 47.7 million, or $ 1.18 a share, which included a charge of $ 21.7 million, or 54 cents a share, related to the early extinguishment of debt, net of tax effects, and a charge of $ 26 million, or 64 cents a share, for the cumulative effect of an accounting change recognizing postretirement health care liabilities.c-Included a loss of $ 600,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and income of $ 3.6 million, or 9 cents a share, in the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary charges of $ 1.7 million, or 4 cents a share, and $ 3.7 million, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, related to the early extinguishment of debt, net of tax effects.Year-ago periods were restated to reflect discontinued operations and an accounting change.

description: Add another entry to the list of museum galleries, wings, sculpture gardens and roof gardens that bear the names of B. GERALD and IRIS CANTOR.

description: Including a 13- by 13-foot atrium in the Payne-Davis house cost the couple an additional $6,000 in 1989, said Bill Davis, of Davis Custom Builders in Stone Ridge, N.Y., the house's builder, who is no relation to Marvin Davis. He said the cost today would be between $10,000 and $15,000.

description: BREAKING up is hard to do, even if the split, as in this case, is an amicable one.

title: Slowly, the New York Region Begins Regaining Its Jobs
description: For the first time since New York City and its suburbs sank into recession in 1989, they showed a slight gain in employment last year, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Cheek vs. Chic: Aspirin Design
description: SUFFERING esthetic aches and pains from too much high-flown design? The Aspirin Design Conference is here to help.

title: France Tries New Tack on Jobs for Young
description: Hoping to forestall new student protests called for Thursday, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur today revoked a Government decree allowing young people to be paid less than the minimum wage and proposed instead that employers be rewarded for hiring those under 25.

title: Patriots Sign Thomas
description: The Patriots have signed BLAIR THOMAS, an unrestricted free agent. The Jets' former No. 1 draft pick signed a one-year $550,000 contract with no money up front.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In New York, DAVE and REBA WHITE WILLIAMS are going to the rescue of a beloved landmark: the carousel in Central Park, which is in serious need of an overhaul.

title: Wendell Niles; Radio and TV Announcer, 89
description: Wendell Niles, a West Coast radio and television announcer for 30 years who also appeared in films, died on Monday at his home in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 89.

title: Woolworth Examining Its Books
description: In an announcement jarringly at odds with a corporate image straight out of a Norman Rockwell painting, the Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that its board had appointed a special committee of outside directors to investigate allegations of accounting irregularities.

description: LOST is a loser, but the U.S. is getting ready to sign on.

description: Baseball American League

description: International

title: Brown & Williamson Dropping Campbell
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation unexpectedly announced yesterday that it would end its relationship with Campbell Mithun Esty in New York after eight and a half years. B.& W. said it would move the creative and media services assignments on its cigarette brands, with more than $40 million in billings, to two of its other shops, Grey Advertising in New York and Tatham Euro RSCG in Chicago.

title: Zulu Leader Is More Isolated But Is Still Proudly Resistant
description: Here in the capital of the last homeland, the last holdout flipped intently through a file.

title: Books of The Times; Keeping the Child, But Not the Father
description: Delusions of Grandma By Carrie Fisher 260 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.

title: OFFSTAGE WITH: Cynthia Phelps; Playing the Tune and Calling It, Too
description: CYNTHIA PHELPS does not exactly blend into the background: not at the New York Philharmonic, where, as principal violist, she sits up front, just to the maestro's right, in Kurt Masur's preferred seating, her alert bearing and model posture enhancing the effect of her striking looks. And certainly not in a little restaurant on Broadway, opposite Lincoln Center, with a photographer hovering to catch her every changing expression.

title: Georgia Rejects Clemency for a Killer Who Says He Is Retarded
description: The Georgia Board of Pardons and Paroles today rejected a last-minute clemency petition from William Henry Hance, a former marine who is appealing his death sentence on the ground that he is mentally retarded and that one of the jurors in his trial now says she never voted for a death sentence.

title: Police Receive Report on a Missing Woman
description: The Nassau County police said today that they had received information indicating that Michelina Abbatiello, a missing 23-year-old Long Island woman, may have taken a taxi to La Guardia Airport last Friday, the day she was last seen by her family and her fiance.

title: Reality Bites: McEnroe Brings His Art to a Senior Circuit 'With Kick'
description: Once upon a time, John McEnroe said senior tennis circuits were a silly waste of time and energy by a bunch of pensioners who would be better off doing something useful, like joining a rock band, captaining a Davis Cup team or opening an eponymous art gallery.

title: Spectrum Chairman Resigns After 9 Days
description: In the latest in a series of seizures at Spectrum Information Technologies Inc., Edward W. Maskaly resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive after only nine days on the job. On Monday, the Manhasset, L.I., company said that two of its three outside directors had resigned, and that five of its inside directors had been asked to step down from the board.

title: Let New York Put Welfare Recipients to Work for a Fair Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: Nintendo Licensing Deal Rocks Acclaim's Stock
description: Shares of Acclaim Entertainment Inc., a leading publisher of video games, tumbled today after Nintendo of America said it had reached an exclusive licensing agreement with WMS Industries, an arcade game company that has created some of Acclaim's most popular games.

title: Around the World in TriBeCa
description: TRIBECA may be the hippest triangle south of Canal Street, but it's sorely missing the kinds of arty shops that make SoHo, north of Canal, a jammed weekend spot.

title: Ira Murchison, 61, Former Track Star
description: Ira Murchison, a sprinter who set world records on two continents and won a gold medal in the 1956 Olympic Games, died on Monday at Ingalls Hospital in Harvey, Ill., outside his native Chicago. He was 61.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. DAVID WESTERN, the Nairobi-based director of strategic planning for the Wildlife Conservation Society, was named director of the Kenya Wildlife Service yesterday. He was appointed by PRESIDENT DANIEL ARAP MOI of Kenya.

title: Justices, at Hearing on New York Case, Raise Pointed Questions Over Church-State Linkage
description: The Supreme Court's fault lines on questions of church and state were on full display today as the Justices heard arguments on the constitutionality of a New York public school district that was created to serve the secular needs of a deeply religious community.

title: U.S. Pressure Ends Canada Supply Pact
description: Under pressure from the Clinton Administration, Bell Canada of Montreal and Northern Telecom Ltd. of Toronto are ending a 55-year preferred-supplier relationship that has given Northern Telecom a first crack at millions of dollars of Canadian telecommunications equipment business every year.

title: Tillman Is Wooed By the Bears, Too
description: Giants running back LEWIS TILLMAN, an unrestricted free agent, received a two-year $1.9 million offer from the Chicago Bears late last night. Tillman also has a multiyear $2.5 million offer from the New England Patriots but has not yet decided which team he will play for next season.

title: Bracknell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a loss provision of $ 4 million for expenses incurred on a major project.c-Net income(Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Leslie Fay Weighs Closing of Plants
description: The Leslie Fay Companies said yesterday that it was considering closing its manufacturing operations in Wilkes-Barre and the Wyoming Valley region of Pennsylvania, a move that would result in layoffs of roughly 1,200 workers.

title: Bloomsbury by Heritage and by Outlook
description: "I'VE got an informal approach," said the textiles designer Cressida Bell as she sat in her London studio painting lamp shades. "But textile design does give me discipline."

title: New Talks Set By Israelis And P.L.O.
description: The P.L.O. agreed early today to resume negotiations with Israel on Palestinian self-rule in the occupied Gaza Strip and Jericho, ending an impasse that began last month after the massacre of Muslim worshipers in Hebron.

title: Culprit in South Africa
description: Accounts differ drastically as to who or what was responsible for Monday's gun battle in downtown Johannesburg that claimed at least 31 lives. But there can be little doubt that the larger responsibility for this tragedy lies with Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the Zulu chief and the only South African leader of consequence who refuses to participate in the national vote set for late April.

title: Italy's Neo-Fascists: Have They Shed Their Past?
description: Half a century after the Fascists' defeat in World War II, the political descendants of Benito Mussolini are set to govern again as part of the right-wing alliance that sprinted to victory this week in Italy's national elections.

title: INSIDE
description: Arab-Israeli Talks to Resume

title: Sports of The Times; Cowboys' 'Three-peat' Triangle
description: THIRTY years ago Jerry Jones wrecked Barry Switzer's car. Yesterday, the Dallas Cowboys' owner finally made it up to him.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Windfall: the Brokers' View
description: Commodity traders and brokers here, shown reports of Hillary Rodham Clinton's dazzling trading profits from October 1978 to the next July, said it might well be impossible to determine whether they were based on luck or skill.

title: Love Triangle Ends In Death for 2 Active In Church in Queens
description: In a love triangle that turned deadly, a Queens woman shot the church choir director she shared a house with and a member of the choir with whom he was also romantically involved, the police said yesterday.

title: Critic's Notebook; Music That Looks for the Best in an Ugly World
description: Bringing Easter up to date is a problem for Christians. Indeed, when liturgies and music are especially beautiful, they can subvert as well as inspire. We float on the ancient language of the Book of Common Prayer, roll with its cadences, divorce our sensibilities from hard meanings therein. It is no surprise that modern churchmen have devised plainer, uglier words for their services and substituted guitars for organs. Lovely music at one point may have brought God closer. Now it seems almost in the way.

title: Nameless Dead In Sea Tragedy Now Identified
description: For nearly 10 months, the bodies of six Chinese men who drowned as they tried to swim ashore from the ill-fated Golden Venture have lain unidentified -- first in refrigerated vaults at the New York City Medical Examiner's office and now in a collective grave in New Jersey.

title: Albany Plan Would Create A New Prison
description: Seeking to reduce prison overcrowding, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders agreed today on a $44.6 million plan to convert a state psychiatric hospital into a 750-bed prison, the first time the correctional system will have been expanded since 1991.

title: HOUSE PROUD
description: SHORT of camping out, there isn't much more Marvin Davis and Cathie Payne could do to enjoy the outdoors at their country house in Woodstock, N.Y.

description: Year-ago year's share earnings is pro-forma to reflect its initial public offering in September 1992 and its conversion to a C corporation from an S corporation.

description: Kurt Ollmann Baritone Weill Recital Hall

title: State Banks Win on Sale Of Annuities
description: The Court of Appeals, New York State's highest court, yesterday gave state-chartered banks the right to sell annuities, a form of investment usually sold by insurance companies.

title: When Cleaners Don't Clean
description: IT starts with promises and a coupon, but often ends with ruined fabric and intimidation. The world of in-home cleaning services can be treacherous.

title: Into Banking's Future, Electronically
description: The flat brick building is barely visible from the wide highway behind the White Castle hamburger shop, but it is the busiest of more than 350 bank branches operated by Huntington Bancshares, which is based here.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST NEW YORK CITY MAYOR AND LABOR AGREE ON SEVERANCE Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the municipal labor unions announced that they had reached agreement on a package of severance offers that the Mayor hopes will cut 7,600 jobs from New York City's payroll without widespread layoffs. A1. FRIENDS IDENTIFY 6 DEAD COMPANIONS For nearly 10 months, the bodies of six Chinese men who drowned as they tried to swim ashore from the ill-fated Golden Venture have lain unidentified. But what has been a mystery to the authorities has been known all along to other passengers of the Golden Venture. Many said they were simply never asked. A1.

title: Rights Groups Fault China's List of Those Held as Dissidents
description: Human rights groups today challenged the accuracy of data on political prisoners provided recently to Secretary of State Warren Christopher by China.

title: Florida Weighs Fees for Its Computer Data: Some See Profits; Others, Too High a Price
description: Prodded by local governments, which see potential for profit in the growing body of public records being stored electronically, Florida lawmakers are considering a proposal to charge fees based on volume for government records stored on computers. The information is available free in paper form.

title: Anheuser-Busch Backs Network
description: Anheuser-Busch, the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, became a sponsor of The Baseball Network yesterday, giving the fledgling joint venture among Major League Baseball, NBC and ABC a much-needed jolt of financial support.

title: Calendar: From Design To Gardens and Glass
description: Design and Architecture Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; (212) 860-6321.

title: Review/Cabaret; Song and Singer Join In an Emotional Fusion
description: That perfect moment when a singer and song find a transcendent emotional fusion is a goal devoutly pursued but hardly ever realized in cabaret performance. Nancy LaMott, a singer who has grown steadily in depth and musicality over the last decade, achieved it on Tuesday evening in the Chestnut Room of Tavern on the Green with her medley of two Stephen Sondheim ballads from "Merrily We Roll Along."

title: 10 Are Killed In French Sub On Exercises
description: Ten sailors died today in an accident aboard a French nuclear-propelled submarine that was taking part in naval exercises in the Mediterranean off Toulon, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: Journal; You'll Always Walk Alone
description: To any American who was around in the 1950's, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d were as corny as Kansas in August -- and as much a part of the decade's oppressively sunny landscape as Ike, backyard barbecues and Ozzie and Harriet.

title: Villanova Turns It Around to Claim Title
description: Villanova buried itself under an avalanche of bad 3-point shots in the first half of the National Invitation Tournament championship game last night. Then, in the second half, the Wildcats used them to dig their way out.

title: Assassination Mysteries
description: A special prosecutor arrived here today as evidence mounted of possible wider involvement in the assassination last week of the governing party's presidential candidate. Two men have been charged, and at least two others remain under suspicion.

title: The New Hire: Glorious Record, Outrageous Past
description: When Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, introduced Barry Switzer yesterday as the Cowboys' new head coach, he recalled that Switzer was his freshman football coach at the University of Arkansas and was also in charge of his freshman dorm.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Blues Stop Panthers Curtis Joseph stopped 27 shots as the St. Louis Blues beat the Florida Panthers, 3-1, last night in Miami. Joseph's play in goal and third-period goals by Brendan Shanahan and Peter Stastny were the difference as the Blues slowed the expansion Panthers' drive to the playoffs. Florida, currently eighth in the Eastern Conference, remained 4 points ahead of Philadelphia and 5 in front of the Islanders in the battle for the final playoff spot. (AP) Whalers 3, Blackhawks 2: Andrew Cassels scored with 1 minute 15 seconds left in overtime as host Hartford broke a four-game losing streak with a victory over Chicago. (AP)

title: Campaign by Police in Los Angeles Changes After Slaying of Japanese
description: One rests atop Vergee's Palace de Bella Donna, beyond a sister billboard for "Naked Gun 33 1/3," near Crenshaw and 48th -- a few blocks west of the vortex of the 1992 riots. It shows a man, masked and menacing, aiming his gun at an unsuspecting woman as she approaches her car.

title: Cable TV Test For Rochester
description: The Rochester Telephone Corporation said today that the Federal Communications Commission had approved its application to test video-on-demand services in 100 homes here.

title: At Utah Hospital, Innovative Way to Track Medical Quality
description: In the mid-1980's, the medical staff at LDS Hospital here took on a seemingly contradictory mission: to cut medical costs and also raise the quality of care. For help, they turned to a sophisticated computer system they had just installed.

description: Finicky Ficus

title: Nets Rise A Rung In the East
description: The Nets' 9-6 record for March hardly compares with the 14-0 mark of the rival Knicks. Still, by achieving a 111-101 victory over the Miami Heat at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, the Nets made it eight straight at home and moved half a game ahead of the Heat in the Eastern Conference playoff race.

title: Bareheaded, Women Slain In Algiers
description: Suspected Muslim fundamentalists in Algeria killed two unveiled young women today, enforcing a vow made last month that women who do not cover their heads in public would join a list of targets that includes the army, the police, secularist intellectuals, artists, journalists and foreigners.

title: Bridge
description: Those who argue about heredity and environment would find food for thought in some bridge families. Norman Kay has long been one of America's best players, and earlier this month came within an imp of winning the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship in Cincinnati and adding to his large collection of titles.

title: Deadly Blaze Tied to Trash Atop a Stove
description: Firefighters said yesterday that they believe trash atop a gas stove started the fire in a SoHo apartment building that killed two firefighters and critically burned a third.

description: International A3-11 U.S. DROPS EXPORT CONTROLS The Clinton Administration scrapped virtually all export controls on shipments of telecommunications equipment and computers to China, Russia and most other former Communist countries. A1

title: Those Streaking Knicks Are Most Thankful for Ample Depth
description: If not for their depth and resiliency, the Knicks' extraordinary winning streak would be over.

title: A New Bidder for Banesto
description: Banco Central Hispano will join the bidding for majority control of the Banco Espanol de Credito, S.A., the troubled Spanish bank known as Banesto, a spokeswoman for Banco Central said.

title: Commodities Broker Has History of Legal Trouble
description: The broker who the White House says was used by Hillary Rodham Clinton to trade commodities futures has a record of regulatory and legal difficulties and was forced into bankruptcy after he was sued by customers and traders who said he had lost millions of their dollars.

title: Sports of the Times; Iron Mike Stumbles as a Scholar
description: THE news that Mike Tyson, inmate No. 922335 in the Indiana Youth Center in Plainfield, Ind., flunked his high school equivalency test indicates that the former heavyweight champion may still be having difficulties with English and math, as well as his attitude.

title: Review/Dance; Sampling the Wares Of 7 Choreographers
description: The seven new dances offered on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater were usually inventive; nothing in them looked either awkward or inappropriate. But there were few revelations in this presentation, part of Dance Theater Workshop's Fresh Tracks series of choreographic showcase programs. The best pieces dealt with strange, even inexplicable, emotional states, which nevertheless were made to seem of the utmost importance.

title: That Marbled Look
description: AT some time in your life, you've probably walked on Fritztile. It may be under your feet this very moment. It is showing up everywhere, from Los Angeles Metro stations to Pennsylvania Station in New York.

title: Russians Agree to Review $5 Export Tax on Oil
description: Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown said today that he had won a commitment from the Russian Government to review a controversial $5-a-barrel export tax on oil that is threatening major American oil investments in this country.

title: Store Manager Slain in Brooklyn
description: Marvin Wildstein fell to his knees and pleaded for his life, but he was shot to death anyway, witnesses said, in what appeared to be a robbery yesterday morning at the plumbing supply store he managed in Brooklyn.

title: It's a Tumultuous Time Within a Pro Football Business Subsidiary
description: National Football League Properties, whose licensed goods generated $2.5 billion in retail sales last year and whose three decades of success have taught other sports leagues how to market themselves, is in turmoil from a management upheaval and an internal audit of its business practices.

title: Italy's 3-Headed Monster
description: A foreigner needs some temerity to criticize the choice freely made by Italy's voters in this week's parliamentary election. Italians can manage their own affairs. But Italy is too important a nation for the health of its polity and economy to be a matter of indifference to the outside world.

title: April 24 Runoff Set In Salvador Election
description: With the vote count slowed by charges of fraud, El Salvador's election authorities confirmed today that a runoff election will be needed to decide the presidential race and that one is scheduled for April 24.

title: Arkansas Secrets
description: There will be plenty of time to explore whether laws were violated when the Clintons went into the land development business with James and Susan McDougal or when George Stephanopoulos and other White House aides meddled with Treasury Department investigations. For the moment, it is enough to ponder the fluid morality implicit in the Clintons' tax returns and the records of Mrs. Clinton's short but profitable career as a commodities trader.

title: ITT Offers New Initiatives That Are Part of Revamping
description: The ITT Corporation announced several new initiatives yesterday that are part of the company's plan to restructure into more strategically focused businesses.

title: CNN Charged Over Tapes Of Noriega
description: The Cable News Network was charged with contempt of court today on the recommendation of a special Federal prosecutor, who said the network had "knowingly and willfully" disobeyed a judge's order in 1990 not to broadcast tape recordings of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega while the former Panamanian dictator was in jail here.

title: Trenton Committee Snags On School Spending Plans
description: A committee that was supposed to remove politics from the thorny issue of public school financing in New Jersey, deciding once and for all how the state should achieve educational and financial equity in its schools, today demonstrated just how difficult that proposition may be.
